SEFA ska bidra till att stärka kapacitet hos lokala och regionala aktörer (offentliga och privata), reducera risker och bidra till kommersiell bärkraftighet för att på så sätt accelerera hållbara energiinvesteringar genomförda av den privata sektorn.
SEFA inriktar sig framförallt på att angripa hinder och risker för utveckling och driftsättning av projekt inom tre områden: Förnybara isolerade elnät, baskraft från förnybara energikällor och energieffektivisering.

The Sustainable Energy Fund for Africa Special Fund (SEFA 2.0) is a multi-donor fund for renewable energy and energy efficiency managed by the African Development Bank (AfDB). So far Denmark, Norway, Italy, USA and Spain are contributing to SEFA. The Nordic Development Fund plans to make a decision on support for SEFA in 2020. The agreement party for SEFA is AfDB.
The purpose of SEFA is to help increase access to sustainable energy in Africa by financing sustainable energy projects and reform processes. SEFA will support the development and implementation of renewable and energy efficiency investments by contributing to reducing the risks during a project cycle, from early project development phases to project implementation. SEFA will contribute to strengthening the capacity of local and regional actors (public and private), reducing risks and contributing to commercial sustainability in order to accelerate sustainable energy investments carried out by the private sector.
In particular, SEFA focuses on tackling obstacles and risks for the development and commissioning of projects in three areas: Green Mini-Grids, Green baseload and energy efficiency.

Syftet med SEFA har sedan tidigare beredning inte ändrats och dess mål står kvar. Dock har SEFA i och med COVID-19 pandemin i sin verksamhet utvecklat ett åtgärdspaket som syftar till att säkra den afrikanska kontinentens hittills åstadkomna landvinningar när det gäller en grön och hållbar energisektorutveckling med ett fokus på distribuerade energitjänster till kunder som saknat tillgång till dessa, samt att stärka förmågan inom hälsosektorn att hantera pandemin. Sida bedömer att de tillägg i verksamheten som görs till följd av COVID-19 pandemin ligger inom ramen för SEFA:s ursprungliga målsättning. Därutöver har SEFA i dialog med Sida tagit fram ett förslag till att utveckla en garantiprodukt och därmed ytterligare bredda sitt utbud av finansiella instrument riktade till de aktörer som utvecklar, bygger och driver isolerade elnät. Anledningen till att Sida bedömer att det är relevant att stötta utvecklingen av en garantiprodukt till denna sektor är att isolerade elnät enligt Internationella Energiorganet står för 30% av de nya elanslutningar som behöver göras för att uppnå allmän tillgång till el i Afrika söder om Sahara och att denna sektor behöver växa betydligt från dagens situation om målet om allmän eltillgång ska kunna nås. Sidas bedömning är att en garantiprodukt väl skulle komplettera de finansiella instrument som SEFA idag har tillgång till.

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 13.a - Fullfölja det åtagande som de utvecklade länder som är parter i Förenta nationernas ramkonvention om klimatförändringar gjort gällande en målsättning att till 2020 gemensamt mobilisera 100 miljarder US-dollar årligen från alla typer av källor för att tillgodose utvecklingsländernas behov vad gäller meningsfulla begränsningsåtgärder och insyn i genomförandet samt så snart som möjligt finansiera och operationalisera den gröna klimatfonden fullt ut.

13.a - Implement the commitment undertaken by developed-country parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change to a goal of mobilizing jointly $100 billion annually by 2020 from all sources to address the needs of developing countries in the context of meaningful mitigation actions and transparency on implementation and fully operationalize the Green Climate Fund through its capitalization as soon as possible.
17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

In particular, SEFA focuses on tackling obstacles and risks for the development and commissioning of projects in three areas: Green Mini-Grids, Green baseload and energy efficiency.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sustainable Energy Fund for Africa Special Fund (SEFA 2.0) är en fond med flera givare (Multi-Donor Trust Fund, MDTF) för förnybar energi och energieffektivisering som förvaltas av Afrikanska utvecklingsbanken (AfDB). Hittills bidrar Danmark, Norge, Italien, USA och Spanien till SEFA. Nordiska Utvecklingsfonden planerar att fatta beslut om stöd till SEFA under 2020. Avtalspart för SEFA är AfDB.
Syftet med SEFA är att bidra till att öka tillgången till hållbar energi i Afrika genom att finansiera hållbara energiprojekt och reformprocesser. SEFA ska stötta utveckling och genomförande av förnybara och energieffektiviseringsinvesteringar genom att bidra till att reducera riskerna under en projektcykel, från tidiga projektutvecklingsfaser till att projekt driftsätts. SEFA ska bidra till att stärka kapacitet hos lokala och regionala aktörer (offentliga och privata), reducera risker och bidra till kommersiell bärkraftighet för att på så sätt accelerera hållbara energiinvesteringar genomförda av den privata sektorn.
SEFA inriktar sig framförallt på att angripa hinder och risker för utveckling och driftsättning av projekt inom tre områden: Förnybara isolerade elnät, baskraft från förnybara energikällor och energieffektivisering.

Sida bedömer att de tillägg i verksamheten som görs till följd av COVID-19 pandemin ligger inom ramen för SEFA:s ursprungliga målsättning. Därutöver har SEFA i dialog med Sida tagit fram ett förslag till att utveckla en garantiprodukt och därmed ytterligare bredda sitt utbud av finansiella instrument riktade till de aktörer som utvecklar, bygger och driver isolerade elnät. Anledningen till att Sida bedömer att det är relevant att stötta utvecklingen av en garantiprodukt till denna sektor är att isolerade elnät enligt Internationella Energiorganet står för 30% av de nya elanslutningar som behöver göras för att uppnå allmän tillgång till el i Afrika söder om Sahara och att denna sektor behöver växa betydligt från dagens situation om målet om allmän eltillgång ska kunna nås. Sidas bedömning är att en garantiprodukt väl skulle komplettera de finansiella instrument som SEFA idag har tillgång till.

17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

title.narrative: Letter of Committment Sida SEFA Amendment
Decision on Amendment of Contribution- SEFA

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att stärka det syriska civilsamhällets (SCS) förmåga att agera som en kraft för demokratisk förändring, fred och stabilitet, för att stödja övergångsrättvisa, och att främja respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och medborgerliga friheter genom projektstöd till mindre organisationer, kapacitetsstöd och påverkansarbete. Stödet innehåller tre delprojekt; Syria Inline, Syria Online och Syria Outline. Varje delprojekt har ett specifikt mål:
1) Syria Inline har följande övergripande mål: Syrian Civil Society (SCS) i Syrien har kapacitet att ta rollen som inflytelserik aktör för fred, stabilitet och positiv förändring i det syriska samhället.
2) Syrien Online har följande övergripande mål: Syrier har tillgång till en säker online-plattform för att få kunskap och färdigheter för att ta rollen som inflytelserik och effektiv aktör för fred, stabilitet och positiv förändring i Syrien.
3) Syria Outline har följande övergripande mål: att stärka syrier, särskilt kvinnor och ungdomar i grannländerna, så att de kan göra röster inifrån Syrien hörda och genom att stödja nätverk med syriska civilsamhällsorganisationer som arbetar med rättighetsfrågor och påverkansarbete.
The intervention’s total budget is 47,506,025 SEK, out of which the organization’s funding is 18 779 085 approximately SEK (1,741,397 million EURO) from DANIDA, 7 603 461SEK (705,074 EURO) approximately from the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 4 142 103 SEK (384,100 EURO) approximately from Holland and 17 000 000 SEK (1,741,397 EURO) from Sida. In addition, Approximately 4 542 136 million SEK (421,175 million USD) of the intervention budget will be forwarded to organizations.
Den totala budgeten för projektet är 47,506,025 kronor varav 18 839 965 kronor (1 741 397 miljoner EURO) är från DANIDA, 7 603 461 kronor (705,074 EURO) är från det franska utrikesministeriet,4 142 103 SEK (384,100 EURO) från Holland och 17 000 000 SEK (1 741 397 EURO) från Sida. Cirka 4 542 136 kronor (421,175 USD) av budgeten kommer att gå till organisationer som arbetar i Syrien.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The intervention aims at strengthening the Syrian civil society (SCS) capacities to act as a force for democratic change, inclusive peace and stability, to support transitional justice, and to promote respect for human rights and civil liberties using different tools and approaches including advocacy, lobbying and policy making". This contribution is a continuation of the previous contribution (52030306) and the overall experience of the previous support has been positive. The new proposed project includes 3 projects, Syria Inline, Syria Online and Syria Outline. Each of the projects has a specific goal:
1) Syria Inline has the following overall goal: Syrian civil society (SCS) in Syria is empowered and skilled to take the role of influential and effective agents of peace, stability and positive change in their communities and in Syrian society.
2) Syria Online has the following overall goal: Syrians have access to a safe and secure online platform where they acquire skills, knowledge, and resources, and empower each other to take the role of influential and effective agents of peace, stability and positive change in their communities and in Syrian society.
And 3) Syria Outline has the following overall goal: To empower Syrians, especially women and youth, whether in neighboring or host countries, to amplify the voices of Syrians inside Syria and advocate for their causes and rights and to support networks of active advocates for Syrian civil society positions and policy recommendations.
The intervention’s total budget is 47,506,025 SEK, out of which the organization’s funding is 18 779 085 approximately SEK (1,741,397 million EURO) from DANIDA, 7 603 461SEK (705,074 EURO) approximately from the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 4 142 103 SEK (384,100 EURO) approximately from Holland and 17 000 000 SEK (1,741,397 EURO) from Sida. In addition, Approximately 4 542 136 million SEK (421,175 million USD) of the intervention budget will be forwarded to organizations.

The intended outcome of this programme is "Syrian civil society (SCS) capacities are strengthened to act as a force for democratic change, inclusive peace and stability, to support transitional justice, and to promote respect for human rights and civil liberties using different tools and approaches including advocacy, lobbying and policy making". This programme includes 3 projects, Syria Inline, Syria Online and Syria Outline. Each of the projects has a specific objective: 1) Syria Inline has the following overall goal: Syrian civil society (SCS) is empowered and skilled to take the role of influential and effective agents of peace, stability and positive change in their communities and in Syrian society. and the following objectives: - Build the capacities of Syrian initiatives, and CBOs to transfer them from nascent organizations to developed and sustained ones. - Support Syrian initiatives, CBOs, and CSOs with the needed resources to implement programs that would affect local contexts and national dialogue and policy. - Support networking between members of Syrian civil society to increase communication and effectiveness and provide the needed resources to implement joint actions by Syrian civil society member organizations. 2) Syria Online has the following overall goal: Syrians have access to a safe and secure online platform where they acquire skills, knowledge, and resources, and empower each other to take the role of influential and effective agents of peace, stability and positive change in their communities and in Syrian society. and the following objectives: - To support safe online networking among Syrian individuals and initiate online discussions and dialogue. - To build the capacities of Syrian individuals and increase their knowledge of democracy, human rights, and civil society; and enhance their professional, organizational, and technical skillsets. - To support Syrians with the needed resources to create content that would enrich the Syria Online platform and the discussions held therein. 3) Syria Outline has the following overall goal: To empower Syrians, especially women and youth, whether in neighboring or host countries, to amplify the voices of Syrians inside Syria and advocate for their causes and rights and to support networks of active advocates for Syrian civil society positions and policy recommendations. and the following objectives: - To support active networks of Syrian CSOs, policy and decision makers, and individuals especially women and youth to increase participation in decision making, public affairs, and policy making in elevating Syrian voices from the ground and bridging and linking Syrians inside and outside. - To build the capacities of Syrian CSOs, and individuals and increase their knowledge on advocacy, building networks and initiatives, and political and civic participation. - To support Syrian individuals with the needed resources to implement advocacy campaigns or initiatives that would affect policy making or promote joint positions and messages amplifying voices from the ground. Gender is not reflected in the objectives, Theory of Change, activities and indicators. Indicators presented in the logframe are not disaggregated by sex. it is only mentioned in the proposal that Baytna Syria has to date, supported 42 gender equality projects across the areas in which it operates and that women’s participation in all capacity-building activities it conducts is no less than 40%. After dialogue with Baytna and based on Sida's request, the logframe has been revisitted and a master logframe has been submitted however didn't reflect gender sensitivity.

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNFPA - Country Programme Support DRC

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Denna insats syftar till att förstärka UNFPA: s kapacitet att leverera de resultat som anges i organisationens landprogram för Demokratiska Republiken Kongo under perioden 2020-2023.
I DRK är alla indikatorer som rör kvinnors hälsa, sexuella och reproduktiva tjänster och rättigheter (SRHR), inklusive tillgång till preventivmedel och ungdomsgraviditeter alarmerande. Dessutom är den övergripande policymiljön när det gäller SRHR och befolkningsdynamik inte anpassad till landets utmaningar. UNFPA är en nyckelaktör i DRK, vars starka insatser inom ramen för dess globala mandat behövs för att stödja både beslutsfattare, genomförande aktörer (internationella och nationella) och olika målgrupper (kvinnor, ungdomar, vårdgivare och institutioner) .
Detta institutionella stöd till UNFPA ger UNFPA flexibilitet, frihet och medel för att positionera sig och ge stöd till aktörer inom SRHR och relaterade frågor i landet.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This contribution aims at strenthening UNFPA's capacity to deliver on the results set by the organisation's country programme for DRC covering the period 2020-2023.
In DRC, all indicators concerning maternal health, sexual and reproductive services and rights (SRHR), including poor access to contraceptives are alarming. Also, overall policy environment with regards to SRHR and population dynamics is inadapted to country's challenges. UNFPA is a key actor in DRC whose strong action within the framework of its global mandate is needed to support both decision makers, implementing actors (international and national), and different target groups (professionals as well as services users, such as the youth).
This contribution proposes providing an institutional support to UNFPA in the country to allow them flexibility, freedom and means to position themselves and provide the needed assistance to the multitude of actors on SRHR and related issues in the country.

This contribution is intended to support the UNFPA DRC country office in contributing to the following objectives: (1) strengthened national capacities to improve financing and develop and implement policies and programmes that address sexual and reproductive health and right’s needs; (2) integrated high quality services delivery and information for maternal health, family planning, Sexually Transmitted Infections/HIV, (3) to ensure that young people and adolescents, especially disadvantaged adolescent’s girls are empowered to have the capacity to claim their rights and access to sexual and reproductive health services; (4) to strengthened national accountability mechanisms to prevent SGBV and promote gender equality and to provide holistic care to victims of SGBV. These objectives will be pursued in stable as well as in humanitarian context.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Yet this is only the first year since this new funding modality was decided upon, UNFPA is very active on all SRHR issues in DRC, comprising provision of PF commodities to selected areas; in supporting the training of humanitarian midwives, in fighting SGBV and assisting the government to prepare next population's census, etc. Selected results that can be mentioned include: - A study on COVID-19 and pregnancy outcomes is being carried out in collaboration with other stakeholders such as WHO and international NGOs; - 8 health facilities in Ebola high risk areas in the provinces of North Kivu and Ituri benefitted from major rehabilitations within the framework of health system strengthening and the nexus-building back better; and 300 health staff from 20 health facilities benefitted from capacity building in PCI. These 20 health facilities equally benefitted from equipment and medical supplies with additional funds from Paul G Allen Foundation; - Two new pools of “humanitarian midwives” from Goma (for 31 midwives from North Kivu, South Kivu, Maniema and Ituri provinces) and Kananga (for 32 midwives from Kasai Central, Kasai, Kasai Oriental and Sankuru provinces) were trained on preparedness and response in humanitarian emergency situations during this reporting period; - Much progress has been made in light of obtaining a law regulating the midwifery profession in the country. The bill was placed on the parliamentary agenda during the current session and referred to commission for in depth analysis. In order to promote better understanding of the bill, two sessions have been organized, firstly to sensitize a group of young parliamentarians and secondly to sensitize a group of parliamentarians on the importance and urgency to have a law regulating the profession of midwifery. The bill is under study at the cultural and social commission of the parliament and is expected to be voted into law by the end of the year. UNFPA is supporting the Midwifery Association of Congo and all stake holders in advocacy efforts to obtain this law; - Communication on GBV protection and prevention measures in collaboration with the Ministry of Gender, Family and Children, Association of female leaders, activists on violence against women, One-Stop Centres for the holistic management of rape and HEFORSHE champions; Youth: 25,000 adolescents received comprehensive sex education at school through the KITUMAINI Initiative; 22,000 adolescents received a comprehensive sex education out of school and entrepreneurial skills through KITUMAINI; 70,000 reusable masks have been produced by young people as part of the offers to prevent against covid 19; 10,000 adolescent girls use youth-friendly sexual and reproductive health services; 1,100 vulnerable people (women, orphans, people with disabilities, students, etc.) benefited from Covid19 protection kit. - Midwifery: UNFPA, working in partnership with Sanru, equipped the newly rehabilitated skills laboratory of the Institut Supérieur des Techniques Médicales (ISTM) Kindu/Maniema with training dummies and other training materials. This was also carried out in the ISTM of Tshikapa/Kasai early this year where Sanru rehabilitated the skills lab of this midwifery training institution which UNFPA equipped with training dummies and training materials; UNFPA has rehabilitated the ISTM of Kalima in Maniema and is negotiating with Sanru to complete with water, hygiene and sanitary installations upgrades; UNFPA and partners are working towards celebrating the international year of midwives and nurses in Kinshasa on the 4th of December. The Swedish Embassy is invited as a key player both for UNFPA and the midwifery profession.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

title.narrative: COVID-19 RBA in SRHR EngenderHealth Ethiopia 2019-2022
COVID-19 RBA inom SRHR EngenderHealth Etiopien 2019-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Den förslagna insatsens syfte är att bidra till rättighetsbaserad samt ökad tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR) services i Etiopien. Detta syfte är högst relevanta i den etiopiska kontexten där det beräknas att över en tredjedel av tonåringar och ungdomar inte har tillgång till sådana tjänster.
Mer specifikt, insatsen syftar till att främja följande rättigheter: -Rätten att själva bestämma om, när och hur många barn man ska ha. -Rätten till SRHR-relaterad information och services. -Rätten att vara fri från könsrelaterat våld.
För att uppnå detta mål kommer unga kvinnors och mäns egenmakt att stärkas som ”rättighetsbärare” för kunna kräva sina SRHR medans service leverantörer och utbildare kommer att stärkas som ”ansvarstagare” för att skapa en möjliggörande miljö för unga människor att utöva sina rättigheter. Insatsens fokus är därför:
-Förbättra kvinnors och flickors förmåga till att utöva sina SRHR. -Förbättra ansvarsutkrävning avseende ansvarstagare och minska diskriminering av kvinnors och flickors tillgång till SRHR-information och service. -Stärka den möjliggörande miljön på interpersonell- och familjenivå för att stödja kvinnor och flickor att kräva och utöva SRHR.
Fokus kommer att omfatta uppföljning och utvärdering och lärande.
Totalt kommer insatsen att nå 7680 flickor och pojkar i Addis Ababa under tre år. Projektet kommer att piloteras i Addis Abeba, med målet att skapa en replikerbar modell för att expandera till andra områden efter piloten. Addis Abeba har valts ut som pilotplats främst på grund av de stora koncentrationerna av unga människor och den ökande migrationsgraden till staden från landsbygden.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The focus of the project is to: -Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR in Ethiopia. -Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services. -Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHR.
In order to achieve this goal, young women and men will be empowered as the “rights holders” to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the “duty bearers” to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights.
Focus will also be on monitoring and evaluation and learning.
The project will reach 7,680 girls and boys over three years. The project will be piloted in Addis Ababa, with the aim to create a replicable model to expand into other areas after the pilot. Addis Ababa has been selected as the pilot location primarily for the large concentrations of young people and the increasing rates of migration into the city from rural areas.

The overarching goal of this intervention is that women and girls fulfil their SRHRs. The specific focus of the project will, furthermore, be on the rights that are at the core of the international conference on population and development (ICPD): right to decide, if, when, and how many children to have; right to SRH-related information and services; and, right to be free from violence. In order to achieve this goal, young women and men will be empowered as the ‘rights holders’ to demand their SRHR while service providers and educators will be strengthened as the ‘duty bearers’ to create an enabling environment for young people to exercise these rights. The project stipulates the following objectives: -Improve women and girls’ agency to exercise their SRHR.-Improve duty bearers’ accountability and reduce discrimination towards women and girls’ access to SRH information and services.-Strengthen the enabling environment at interpersonal and family level to support women and girls to demand and exercise SRHRs. There is also an objective dedicated to monitoring and evaluation as well as learning.

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During 2020, the cooperation partner has, despite Covid-19 related challenges managed to achieve a number of results. These include but are not limited to: - Covid-19 media awareness campaigns that integrated SGBV and SRHR messaging using TV talk shows and radio programmes. These are estimated to have reached approximately 50 million people and 2.5 million people, respectively. - Rapid assessment of weak spots and barriers in SRHR education and the drafting of a curriculum that integrates SRHR and life skills. Based on rapid assessment, using two languages (Amharic and Oromiffa) age-appropriate and educational video spots on SGBV and SRHR were developed and broad casted through one TV station (AfriHealth TV) dedicated for media based education. In addition, the messages were disseminated using social media platforms such as Telegram, Facebook, YouTube and Twitter. Through these intervention, approximately 246,587 young individuals aged between 13-34 were reached. - To improve the knowledge, skills, and attitudes of educators on SRHR integrated with Covid-19 response, the project trained 97 biology teachers (20 females and 77 males), school principals and biology department leads (80 biology teachers, 8 school principals and 8 biology department leads) on adolescent and youth health. This included SRHR, gender-responsive facilitation skills for SRHR topic and transformation manual to enable reflection on harmful norms, biases and prejudices that impede full access to SRHR for young people. - The project collaborated with the Addis Ababa Police Commission to expand helpline services for SGBV response and support. With this intervention, SGBV survivors now have access to support from police officers, psychological counselors and lawyers, and thus can be provided with legal services, counseled, and referred to health facilities. - In addition to the expanded helpline, the project also piloted community-based structures to prevent GBV. This included setting up GBV prevention committees in selected districts in 10 sub-cities and subsequently training 445 committee members, ranging from religious leaders, local police, youth leaders etc. This was done to improve accountability on community level and improve GBV survivor referral systems and data collection for local administrations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Svenska Röda korset Building Resilient and Inclusive Communities (BRIC)
COVID-19 Swedish Red Cross Building Resilient and Inclusive Communities (BRIC)

description.narrative: Building Resilient and Inclusive Communities (BRIC) project aims to contribute healthier, safer and inclusive communities with reduced vulnerabilites and strengthened resilience, and will meet the complex humanitarian needs in conflict-affected States of Rakhine and Shan. This programme contributes to, and is relevant under, the Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation with Myanmar (2018–2022) and there are also linkages to both Sida’s Humanitarian Crisis Analysis for Myanmar 2019, the Strategy for Sweden’s Humanitarian aid (2017-2020) as well as to the Strategy for support via Swedish civil society organisations (2016-2022) and to Sweden’s Policy for Global Development.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Svenska Röda Korset har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering av 15 miljoner SEK för att genomföra programmet "Building Resilient and Inclusive Communities (BRIC)" i Myanmar under perioden april 2020 - mars 2023. Programmets övergripande mål är att bidra till hälsosammare, säkrare och inkluderande samhällen med minskad sårbarhet och stärkt hållbarhet. Programmet möter stora humanitära behov i två konfliktdrabbade stater, Rakhine och Shan.
BRIC-programmet bygger på erfarenheter från ett treårsprojekt (2017-2019) finansierat av Sida's humanitära enhet som svarade på stora humanitära behov i två townships i Rakhine.
Svenska Röda Korset är ansvarig för att uppnå målen och programmet implementeras i nära samarbete med Myanmar Red Cross Society.
BRIC-programmet fokuserar på samhällsbaserade insatser inom basal hälsovård på lokal nivå, vatten och sanitet, skydd och katastrofriskreducering. Insatserna kommer att genomföras i två townships i centrala Rakhine och Norra Shanstaten.
BRIC-programmet är väl förankrat i principerna för nexus (HUM/UTV) där programmets aktiviteter kommer komplettera humanitära insatser och samtidigt bygga hållbarhet.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Swedish Red Cross (SRC) has applied to Sida for funding of 15 million SEK to carry out the "Building Resilient and Inclusive Communities (BRIC) Programme" in Myanmar during the period April 2020-March 2023. With the overall programme objective to contribute to healthier, safer and inclusive communities with reduced vulnerabilities and strengthened resilience, the programme will meet the complex humanitarian needs in conflict-affected states of Rakhine and Shan. SRC will invest additional 3 million SEK from their own fund.
The BRIC programme is built on the experiences and lessons learned of a three years project (2017-2019) funded by Sida's Humanitarian Unit to Swedish Red Cross (SRC) in order to respond to urgent humanitarian needs in two townships of Rakhine State.
Swedish Red Cross will be responsible to achieve the goal above, and this programme will be implemented through a partnership with Myanmar Red Cross Society.
The BRIC programme focuses on community health, WASH, protection and disaster risk reduction which are community based interventions, and will be functioned in two townships of Central Rakhine and Northern Shan States.
The BRIC program is firmly rooted in the principles of nexus (HUM/DEV) where the program's activities will complement humanitarian efforts and at the same time build sustainability.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Internews: Strengthening Rural Radio for impartial information in DRC
COVID-19 Stärkt landsbygdsradio för opartisk information i Demokratiska republiken Kongo

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Projektet är utformat för att säkerställa hållbara politiska reformer samt digitala hållbara oberoende medier och civilsamhälle i DRK. För att åstadkomma detta behövs tillräcklig kompetens och kunskap samt tillförlitliga verktyg så att medborgarna erhåller korrekt och opartisk information. Politiska reformer, digitalt aktiverade och hållbara oberoende medier och civilsamhället i Demokratiska republiken Kongo för att ha de färdigheter, kunskap och verktyg som de behöver för att nå medborgarna med korrekt och opartisk information som främjar inkludering och ansvarsutkrävande.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project is designed to ensure a resilient, policy reforms, digitally-enabled and sustainable independent media and civil society in DRC to have the skills, knowledge and tools they need to reach citizens with accurate and impartial information that promotes inclusion and accountability

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt

description.narrative: This annual narrative report provides a detailed overview of the Internews Year1 achievements of the "Strengthening Rural Radio for Impartial Information in DR Congo. The report shows progressive that the intervention is developing good outcomes and reaching results progressively. The partners have been able to carry out several radio productions, the training sessions, feuilleton and magazines, etc. The project has registered delays and weakness in building strong understanding project goals between Internews and Kandindi broadcast radio. Due to Covid19 sanitary and travel restrictions, Internews adapted Year 1 activity in building awareness of COVID19. These contributed in miss interpretation of project goal by radios who has been contracted to produce and broadcast feuilleton, magazine and feedback shows based on project thematic areas on democracy, gender and women/human rights, health, conflict prevention, environment and infrastructures, etc. The health crisis and collaboration with local partners with little experience in project management were major challenges during this first year of implementation. Various support and capacity building plans were rolled-out to strengthen the management capacities of the six project implementation partners (Agence Kandindi, Association Congolaise des Femmes de la Presse Ecrite/ACOFEPE, Fédération des Radios de Proximité du Congo/FRPC, Justicia TV, Radio ISDR Bukavu, Radio Kalinga/Ile d'Idjwi). In this regard, the project has been particularly resilient, flexible and demonstrates an agile and proactive capacity to adapt to this unique context. Despite the challenges that project started with, a gradual ownership of the project by implementing partners, significant progress were made during the first year in achieving the project's main objective of promoting a more open and dynamic media sector that contributes to more responsive and transparent institutions, improving access to independent public interest information in urban and rural areas with a special focus on women and youth. During the first year of implementation, the team has designed and implemented an advocacy strategy to obtain a new legal and fiscal framework for community radio stations, which will help to strengthen their editorial independence. An advocacy plan and a call for a moratorium to suspend the existing fiscal scheme to which community and association radio stations are subjected to were developed during the first year of the project. The project team is currently working to ensure that the new legal and fiscal status of community radios is included in the bill amending the 1996 law on freedom of the press that will be introduced during the March 2021 parliamentary session. A campaign to mobilize public opinion in favor of the new legal and fiscal status of community radios was launched in November 2020 and will continue in year 2 of the project. Internews trained partners’ trainers to improve their training capacity on identified gaps and build their ability to train their respective members, local partners and stakeholders. The objective of this strategy is to develop their own training capacity to ensure the sustainability of the project. In addition to above, Internews supported training workshops for women journalists and editors to increase the production of gender-sensitive media content, coaching sessions and mentorship for radio partners’ correspondents, production of magazines, radio debates on local governance, popular expression forums, as well as workshops for women leaders to advocate for better access to media for women.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa
CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa

description.narrative: Insatsens "Klimatförändringar Budget och Finansiering i Afrika" mål är att stödja Afrikanska regeringar i att integrera responsen på klimatförändringarna i sina ordinarie budget- och planeringsprocesser. Detta uppnås genom dialogarbete och fallstudier, stödja regeringarna i att utforma och genomföra publik finansiell förvaltning (Public Finance Management, PFM) och att stödja reformarbete som bidrar till transparens och ansvarsfullhet. Programmets övergripande mål är att reducera klimatförändringarnas effekter och att öka motståndskraften i Afrikas länder samt att stödja regeringar i Afrika att utnyttja möjligheterna för nå en rättvis övergång till noll kolutsläpp och för att minska koldioxidutsläppen .Afrikas förhandlingsposition enligt Parisavtalet förväntas stärkas genom programmet och bidra till ökade finansieringsmöjligheter för åtgärder till klimatanpassning. CABRI ( Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspart. Partner är UNDP (United Nations Developmment Programmes), IIED (International Institute Environmental Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Den totala projektbudgeten är 12 800 000 SEK för en förstudie för ett år. Programmet är femårigt i sin implementering fas och Sida stödjer en ettårig förstudieperiod. Den Pan- Afrikanska institutionen CABRI (The Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspartner. CABRI´s samarbetspartner är UNDP, IIED (International Institution for Environment and Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Detta är en förstudie på ett år vilken ska förbereda en efterföljande implementeringsfas på fyra år. Programmet har tre komponenter: 1) Syd- syd lärande avseende att integrera klimatförändrings insatser i budgetprocesser. Denna komponent leds av CABRI. CABRI ska också utveckla en webbaserad portal och ett nätverk av experter samt koordinera insatsen i sin helhet. 2) Landbaserat stöd till utvalda länder i form av teknisk assistans till regeringar och statliga myndigheter som arbetar med åtgärder för klimatförändringar och att integrera dessa i ländernas budget processer. Detta arbete leds av UNDP 3) Klimatfinansiering och förvaltning vilket ska stärka översynen, transparensen och ansvarsfullheten bland aktörerna. Detta arbete leds av IIED och IBP.

The primary objective of the Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa (IBFCCA) is to integrate Climate Change into the budget process. CABRI is requesting 1 247 738 USD for an inception phase of 12 months. 30 000 USD will be commissioned by Sida for an external Management and Control audit. The planned programme is for another four years. The Pan African institution, the Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative, CABRI will be Sida´s agreement partner and take the lead working closely with key implementing partners; UNDP, IIED International Institution for Environment and Development and IBP (International Budget Partnership). The inception phase aims to prepare the Implementation Phase securing effectiveness and funding. The design of the Implementation Phase will aim to integrate gender fully into the programme and define specific gender-related initiatives. The program has three components: 1)South-South learning on integrating CC in fiscal and budget planning will be led by the Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative (CABRI), who will also support a web-based resource and a cadre of related expertise and provide overall coordination. 2) Country-based work will support the government institutions involved in CC integration in two countries, with technical assistance from UNDP. 3) Climate finance governance work will strengthen oversight, transparency and accountability actors and practices and will be led by the International Budget Partnership (IBP) and International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED). The programme will respond to a demand from governments and theirs increasing interest for budget tagging flows mechanism to see the effectivity and efficiency of current allocated budget of Climate Change spending. The IBFCCA programme will enhance and foster capacity building of the African regional institutions and the national governments to better access climate finance. Relevance to Sweden´s Development Cooperation Strategy for Sub-Saharan Africa: The proposal falls in the category of support area 1, sub -support area 1.2; Strengthened capacity of regional actors to work towards increased resilience against climate change and natural disasters, including capacity for food security. It focuses on Ministries of Finance to become involved in climate policy and to mobilise the wider national and local budgetary process involving government, legislatures and civil society. The Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) are key. NDCs embody efforts by each country to reduce national emissions and adapt to the impacts of climate change.

This is an inception phase (one year) of a wider another four year implementation programme. The wider objectives (full programme) are reduced CC impact with a gender focus and a reduced adaptation gap and promoting opportunities for just transition to low carbon economy. Immediate impact, institutional support: Reform and strengthening of the budget process of countries MoFs, strengthened pan-African negotiating position, empowered CSOs and accontability actors. Further potential impacts are increased levels of CC and gender expenditure public/private, increased effectiveness of expenditure through improved Climate Change Impact Assessment. Outcomes by components respectively: Component A (CABRI) Active liaison officials/champions, African CC/Gender integration effective and networks working on CC Gender Integration. Component B (UNDP) Government approval of country review, government approval of pilot reform. Component C (IIEED/IBP) Climate Finance Accountability (CFA) by governments, state and non-state Accountability Actors, Engagement in peer exchange and Workshops in strengthening Climate Finance Assessment. Ouptputs starting during inception phase: Component A: case studies, peer exchange events, pilot IBFCCA portal, CC/Gender integration cadre operation.There will be four peer exchange and learning events during the Inception Phase, two of which will be led by CABRI under Component A. The third will be organized jointly by CABRI and IBP/IIED, with IBP/IIED organizing the preparation and CABRI organizing the actual peer exchange and learning event. The fourth will be organized jointly by CABRI and UNDP, again with UNDP organizing the preparation and CABRI organizing the event. Two specific reports will be prepared to inform the preparation of the Implementation Phase, one related to gender and the other to Covid. These reports will be self-standing and may be attached as annexes or working papers to the Implementation Phase Document. B: Country reviews differnt methods as CPEIR (CC Public Expenditure and Institutional Review), CCFF (Climate Change Financial Framework), CCIA (Climate Change Impact Assessment) CC tagging. This component will support two country actions in the Inception Phase: the first will be a country review and the second will support piloting a new budget/finance practice. The work will use the methods developed by UNDP Kenya and other relevant ones, with technical and financial support from UNDP Regional Service Centre for Africa, and the extensive experience of the UNDP Regional Hub in Bangkok over the last 8 years. The activities undertaken will be selected and led by country governments. C: Country CFA (Climate Finance Accountability). The Inception Phase will involve a structured programme of capacity building for partner CSOs in 2 of the 4 focus countries (i.e. Ghana, Kenya, Mauritius and Mozambique). IBP and IIED already have some good working relationships with possible partners which will facilitate a rapid start to activities and minimise the constraints caused by the need to work remotely. The collaboration will be based primarily around the preparation of Climate Finance Accountability (CFA) Assessments for each country. The CFAs will provide a stocktake of the current state of climate finance transparency and accountability, including the role of Accountability Actors (AAs), and the “demand side” of climate finance management, including partnerships with civil society organizations (CSOs). It will build on the joint work of the International Budget Partnership (IBP) and International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED). In addition to the stocktake, the CFAs will provide a capacity needs assessment and propose an Action Plan for improving transparency and accountability over the short, mid and long term. A direct result of the inception phase will be a four year proposal of an implementation phase. The following activities are expected to have substantial progress completed by the end of month 8 although the activities may not be completed and dissemination and approval work is unlikely to have taken place. • keynote papers and case studies for the first two peer exchange and learning (i.e. the review of African experience with integration and the gender/CC integration exchange)• two peer exchange and learning (i.e. for the review of experience with CC integration and for gender/CC integration)• the design studies for the portal and the capacity building and cadre• the country review (e.g. CPEIR/CCFF/CCIA)• the pilot reform (e.g. tagging)• the Country Climate Finance Accountability Landscape Assessments and the keynote paper for the third peer exchange and learning on CFAs.

title.narrative: CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa
CABRI Inclusive Budgeting and Financing for Climate Change in Africa

description.narrative: Insatsens "Klimatförändringar Budget och Finansiering i Afrika" mål är att stödja Afrikanska regeringar i att integrera responsen på klimatförändringarna i sina ordinarie budget- och planeringsprocesser. Detta uppnås genom dialogarbete och fallstudier, stödja regeringarna i att utforma och genomföra publik finansiell förvaltning (Public Finance Management, PFM) och att stödja reformarbete som bidrar till transparens och ansvarsfullhet. Programmets övergripande mål är att reducera klimatförändringarnas effekter och att öka motståndskraften i Afrikas länder samt att stödja regeringar i Afrika att utnyttja möjligheterna för nå en rättvis övergång till noll kolutsläpp och för att minska koldioxidutsläppen .Afrikas förhandlingsposition enligt Parisavtalet förväntas stärkas genom programmet och bidra till ökade finansieringsmöjligheter för åtgärder till klimatanpassning. CABRI ( Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspart. Partner är UNDP (United Nations Developmment Programmes), IIED (International Institute Environmental Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Den totala projektbudgeten är 12 800 000 SEK för en förstudie för ett år. Programmet är femårigt i sin implementering fas och Sida stödjer en ettårig förstudieperiod. Den Pan- Afrikanska institutionen CABRI (The Collaborative Africa Budget Reform Initiative) är Sidas avtalspartner. CABRI´s samarbetspartner är UNDP, IIED (International Institution for Environment and Development) och IBP (International Budget Partnership). Detta är en förstudie på ett år vilken ska förbereda en efterföljande implementeringsfas på fyra år. title.narrative: COVID-19 BLIAP - Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific, Phase 3, 2020-2021
COVID-19 BLIAP- Att vara HBTQI-person i Asien och Oceanien, Fas 3, 2020-2021

description.narrative: Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018, first under the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooperation for SouthEast Asia, and then under the the Swedish Government's Regional Strategy for Development Cooopeation for Asia and the Pacific. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities, but from the Global Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation in the areas of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Funds of 5 msek were chanelled through the Global LGBTI partnership with USAID. In total, the Project has received 37 202 000 SEK from Sweden during 2014-2019. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. Phase 1, initiated in 2012, focused on developing an evidence base of the lived experience of LGBTI people through research and the engagement of civil society Groups throughout the region. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. 1: Legal reform and political and civic participation – The project will promote development of an enabling environment for the development and implementation of protective laws and policies that are inclusive of LGBTI people, including antidiscrimination legislation, decriminalization of homosexuality, and legal gender recognition for transgender people. 2: Access to justice, personal security and anti-violence protection – The project will promote fair and equal treatment of LGBTI persons by the justice and law enforcement systems, including improved access to justice and enhanced personalsecurity and antiviolence protection. This will include addressing hate crimes, police abuses, domestic violence and other forms of violence. 3: Health – The project will promote improved access to health and HIV services and address health disparities, including inequitable access to services, pathologization of homosexuality and transgender people, and respect for the bodily integrity of intersex people. This will include the development of policies and guidelines for health care services that are sensitive to and respectful of the health rights of LGBTI people. 4: Economic well-being – The project will promote inclusive, non-discriminatory hiring practices and equitable work environments for LGBTI people to address access to and rights violations in employment. The scope of work will extend to linkages with livelihoods and poverty alleviation programmes, particularly for the most marginalized groups within the LGBTI spectrum. 5: Education – The project will promote LGBTI people’s equitable access to an education system that is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and appropriate to the needs of the 21st century. This will include addressing harassment and bullying, inclusive curricula, and freedom of gender expression in education institutions. Efforts will include ensuring LGBTI population have access to training and education which is seeks to build 21st century skills and capacity for utilizing new technologies. The goal of the project is to promote LGBTI inclusion in Asia Pacific across five development dimensions: political and civic participation, access to justice and personal safety, economic well-being, health and education. The end-of-project outcome is: LGBTI social and economic inclusion in Asia Pacific advanced through promulgation and implementation of protective laws, policies and programmes which mitigate discrimination and violence, ensure access to LGBTI appropriate services.Three lower level or interim outcomes will contribute towards achieving the overall end of project outcome. They are: 1. Improved capacity and commitment of governments and NHRIs to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and programmes and to ensure equitable access to services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.2. Improved capacity and increased participation of LGBTI community groups in dialogue and advocacy with stakeholders – including governments, civil society, NHRIs, the private sector and youth development partners – on the development, implementation and monitoring of LGBTI inclusive and protective laws, policies and practices as well as the promotion of equitable access to opportunities and services that meet the needs of LGBTI people.3. Improved capacity and commitment of the business sector, other private sector actors, and social protection initiatives to develop, implement and monitor LGBTI inclusive policies and programmes supporting access to employment, livelihoods, innovative social entrepreneurship and poverty alleviation. The end-of-project outcome for the previous phase of the project focused on increased capacity and willingness of rights holders and duty bearers to advocate for, develop and implement LGBTI inclusive public lawa, policies and programmes. While BLIAP´s design recoginizes the need to further develop the capacity of rights holders and duty bearers, including affording a higher priority to developing private sector partner capacity committment, this is framed within the context of a more ambitious end-of-project outcome which buold on existing foundations laid by the project to achieve an incresed number of protective laws, policies and programmes which advance LGBTI inclusion.

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) is a regional project implemented by UNDP. It has previously been given funding from Sida between 2014-2018. In 2019 the BLIAP entered into a phase 3 with implementation period 2019-2023 and continued to receive Swedish funds for 2019 activities. The Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) Phase 3 programme builds upon previous work in Phase 1 and 2. BLIAP Phase 3 (2019-2023) will implement a five-year plan strategically focusing on five development dimensions, set out below. These areas of work build on the recommendations of the Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue in 2015 and the achievements of BLIA Phase 2. They also reflect the key areas of inclusion identified through a global consultative process with civil society and stakeholders on the LGBTI inclusion index in 2016. The COVID-19 has created a perfect storm of crises across the region, not just in regards to health: COVID-19 creates a socio-economic crise, disproportionately impacting already marginalized persons within societies and causing significant human rights challenges. The pandemic is disrupting the capacity of LGBTI organisations to respond to challenges, and new ways of working need to be developed. According to UNDP, the crisis also presents an opportunity for transformative change and a possibility to build back more inclusively and sustainabily. Sidas assessment is that a cost extension will allow for UNDP to continue to adapt to changing circumstances and support the LGBTI community in times of crises. It is positive that UNDP works with an expanded approach that focuses on adequate representation by young LGBTI-persons and emerging issues such as LGBTI inclusion in climate action and adaptation. This also strengthens the relevance in relation to the on-going Strategy for Regional Asia and the Pacific (2016-2021).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Being LGBTI in Asia and Pacific (BLIAP) är ett regionalt projekt som genomförs av UNDP. Det har tidigare beviljats medel från Sida mellan 2014–2018. År 2019 gick BLIAP in i fas 3 med genomförandeperioden 2019-2023. Fas 3 av Being LGBTI in the Asia Pacific (BLIAP) bygger på tidigare arbete och resultat i fas 1 och 2 och genomförs med fokus på fem strategiska dimensioner. Dessa arbetsområden bygger på rekommendationer från Being LGBTI in Asia Regional Dialogue under 2015 och resultaten från fas 2. De återspeglar också de områden som identifierades som viktigast att inkludera under en global konsultationsprocess med civila samhället och aktörer kring LGBTI inclusion index 2016. UNDP och Sida har haft en nära dialog kring hur COVID-19 och politisk turbulens har påverkat programmet och dess målgrupp. Att vara HBTQI i Asien och Oceanien ökar risken för marginalisering och social exkludering. COVID-19 skapar inte bara en hälsokris, utan även en socio-ekonomisk kris där redan marginaliserade grupper drabbas extra hårt. Samtidigt skapar krisen också en möjlighet att bygga tillbaka bättre på ett sätt som är mer hållbart och inkluderande, och det finns ett momentum att bygga vidare på. Genom en avtalsändring fortsätter ambassaden att stödja UNDP under 2021 som är det sista året för den regionala strategin för Asien och Oceanien. Ambassadens bedömning är att denna avtalsändring möjliggör för UNDP att fortsätta stödja den regionala HBTQI-communityn under en tid av kris. UNDP har arbetat aktivt för att anpassa stödet till den nya situationen och stöd för ökad digital säkerhet kommer också att ingå i budgeten. Strategirelevansen bedöms ha ökat genom att UNDP arbetar mer integrerat med miljö och klimat, genom att verka för ökad representation av HBTQI-personer inom klimatområdet.

title.narrative: UNIDO LKDF, facilitation and innovative skills development
UNIDO LKDF, facilitering och innovativ kompetensutveckling

description.narrative: The development objective of LKDF 2.0 is to contribute to establishing inclusive, sustainable, and innovative market oriented vocational training systems and job creation in Africa and elsewhere in the era of digitilisation and automation by facilitating knowledge sharing and supporting a wider innovative approach for PPDPs in skills development. The proposal from UNIDO is to through an MSD diagnostic, which will take place during the inception phase, elaborate the theory of change based on a thorough analysis involving stakeholders and identify targets and indicators for measuring achievements linked to he following three strategic priority areas: i) advancing economic competitiveness, ii) creating shared prosperity, and iii) safeguarding the environment. The LKDF 2.0 will directly and indirectly provide support to governments, private sector, training institutions, students and trainees, current and future employees as well as investors to build stronger local economies, create jobs and improve working conditions. The intended end result of the intervention is to offer a strong TVET sector with increased efficiency, productivity, quality and competitiveness: students and trainees will improve their technical skills in line with market needs and will be able to apply them to find decent employments in fields linked to their improved skills. The following indicative outputs are suggested: 1. Partnerships that bridge the skills gap, a market failure, are supported; 2. Market Systems Development approach implemented in the development of new PPDPs; 3. Knowledge generated from PPDP projects is shared through an expanded e-platform and face-to-face meetings; 4. Innovation is promoted by developing future oriented training programmes. During the inception phase, a more elaborated theory of change and results' framework will be developed as well as a risk analysis. It will also take into account the effects or possible effects of the corona pandemic on the project.

UNIDO har inkommit med en förfrågan om stöd till deras kunskaps- och lärandeplattform, Learning and Knowledge Development Facility 2.0, för facilitering av innovativ och efterfrågestyrd kompetensutveckling inom ramen för den globala omställningen som sker till följd av automatisering och digitalisering. Sidas bidrag uppgår till 17 MSEK, 3,4 MSEK per år mellan 2020-2024. Aktivitetsperioden löper till juni 2025. Den första utbetalningen görs i samband med signerandet av avtalet. Sida var med och startade LKDF tillsammans med UNIDO 2012 och stöttade faciliteten 2013-2016.
Omkring en tredjedel av världens 1,8 miljarder unga människor är utan sysselsättning (anställning, skola eller annan utbildning) och ungdomsarbetslösheten är en av de stora globala frågorna för 2000-talet. En miljard unga kommer dessutom att komma ut på arbetsmarknaden under kommande tioårsperiod men bara 40% av dem förväntas kunna få ett av de nu existerande jobben. Det innebär att 600 miljoner jobb måste skapas inom tio år bara för att undvika att den nuvarande ungdomsarbetslösheten ökar. Beroende på effekterna av Covid-19 kan situationen bli ännu värre.
En av de främsta anledningarna till hög ungdomsarbetslöshet i flera utvecklingsländer och länder i transition är ett ökande glapp mellan utbud och efterfrågan på industriella färdigheter. Innehållet och kvalitén av yrkesutbildningsprogrammen matchar inte näringslivets behov av kompetens. Unga nyutexaminerade får således inte jobb medan arbetsgivarna inte hittar kvalificerad personal. Det spär i sin tur på problemen med ungdomsarbetslöshet och påverkar den ekonomiska utvecklingen negativt till följd av uteblivna investeringar.
LKDF 2.0 bygger på en modalitet som har visat sig vara framgångsrik vad gäller att bidra till sysselsättning bland unga genom utbildning inom industriella färdigheter, nämligen Public Private Development Partnerships, PPDPs, eller partnerskap mellan den offentliga och privata sektorn. PPDPs är ett sätt att leverera och finansiera tjänster tillhandahållna av den offentliga sektorn med ett större och bredare utvecklingsgenomslag, bygga oberoende och stärka lokala marknader. Investeringsriskerna, ansvaret och belöningarna delas mellan den offentliga sektorn, den privata sektorn och samarbetsparten. PPDPs används på områden där fattigdomsminskning inte kan uppnås om inte aktörer från näringslivet, den offentliga sektorn och utvecklingsaktörer går samman och där alla har ett gemensamt mål. För att en PPDP ska lyckas måste samarbetet bidra till positiva resultat för samtliga parter.
Värdet med samarbetet eller samverkan är att den privata sektorn säkerställer att läroplaner och kurser är relevanta för industrin medan den tekniska parten, i det här fallet UNIDO, kan föra samman aktörer från det offentliga, näringslivet och utvecklingsaktörer såsom Sida. PPDPs utgör därmed en god grund för att inspirera till läroplanens ackreditering och att andra yrkesskolor strävar efter att efterlikna.
LKDF 2.0 kommer att använda en marknadsansats för att bidra till systemförändring vad gäller PPDPs och den förväntade effekten är att efterfrågestyrd yrkesutbildning erbjuds och sysselsättningen ökar. Följande resultat förväntas: (1) Planer för partnerskap som överbryggar marknadsstörningen som har med kompetensglappet att göra levereras; (2) Bedömningar av marknadssystemutveckling produceras för att informera nya PPDPs; (3) Kunskap/lärdomar från PPDPs tillgängliggörs genom en utökad e-plattform och fysiska möten, och; (4) Kurs/utbildningsförslag med innovativa och framtidsorienterat innehåll utvecklas. Projektet inleds med en sex månader lång inceptionsfas under vilken ett antal strategiska dokument ska tas fram för godkännande innan den andra utbetalningen sker: ett mer utvecklat resultatramverk och förändringsteori baserad på en inkluderande system- och riskanalys och den faktiska efterfrågan från industrin; en strategi för "outreach" för att locka företag och andra aktörer att delta, inklusive andra givare, och en kommunikationsstrategi; en arbetsbeskrivning för projektets styrkommitté, och; förslag på en arbetsplan för det första året av genomförande. Dessutom ska en avdelningsövergripande arbetsgrupp etableras på UNIDO.
Insatsens totala budget är 1,781,445 EUR varav UNIDO finansierar 200,000 EUR och Sida bidrar med 17 MSEK. Projektet förväntas bidra till sysselsättning och till de globala målen 4 (utbildning), 9 (innovation) och 17 (partnerskap).

UNIDO has requested support to their Learning and Knowledge Development Facility, LKDF, 2.0 for the facilitation of demand-driven and innovative skills development in the era of automation and digitization. The Sida contribution amounts to 17 MSEK, 3,4 MSEK per year for five years, 2020-2024. The activity period runs up to June 2025. The first disbursement will be effectuated upon the signature of the agreement. LKDF was initiated by Sida and UNIDO in 2012 and Sida supported the facility between 2013-2016.
With around one third of the world’s 1.8 billion young people neither in employment, education, or training (abbreviated NEET), youth unemployment is one of pressing global issues in the 21st century. Furthermore, one billion more youth will enter the job market in the next decade, but only 40% are expected to find jobs that currently exist. This implies that 600 million jobs will have to be created in 10 years, only to keep pace with projected youth employment rates. Covid-19 may firther aggravate the situation.
One of the main reasons for high youth unemployment in many developing countries and countries in transition is a growing mismatch between the supply and demand of industrial skills. In particular, the content and quality of Technical and Vocational Education and Training programmes in many countries does not match the private sector’s demands. As a result, graduates cannot find jobs while employers cannot find skilled personnel. This further exacerbates the issue of youth unemployment and negatively impacts economic development due to foregone investments.
The LKDF promotes a modality that has proven successful in fostering youth employment through industrial skills training: Public Private Development Partnerships (PPDP), which is a way of delivering and funding public services with wider development impact and building local self-reliance and markets. The investment, risks, responsibilities and rewards are shared between the public sector, the private sector and a development partner. PPDPs are used in areas where poverty reduction cannot be achieved by separating private sector actors, the public sector and development agencies, and where all these actors share a common goal. To make a PPDP successful, it has to create benefits for all parties.
The value proposition is that the private sector partners ensure that the curricula and the training are relevant for the industry, while the technical partners, such as UNIDO, are uniquely positioned to bring together stakeholders from the public sector, the private sector and the development sector. As a result of the above, PPDPs are well-positioned to serve as role models for curricula accreditation and emulation by other TVET Centers.
The LKDF 2.0, will use the Market Systems Development (MSD) Approach to achieve systemic change in PPDPs with the expected outcome that demand-oriented vocational training is offered. The following outputs are planned; (1) Plans for partnerships that bridge the skills gap market failure are delivered; (2) Market Systems Development assessments are produced to inform new PPDPs; (3) Knowledge generated from PPDP projects is made available through an expanded e-platform and face-to-face meetings, and; (4) Training proposals with innovative and future oriented training content are developed. The project will commence with a six months' long inception phase during which a number of strategic documents will be elaborated for approval before the second disbursement: a more developed results' framework and theory of change based on an inclusive system and risk analysis and the actual demand from the industry; an outreach strategy on how to to attract businesses and other actors, including other donors, to join, as well as a communication strategy; the terms of reference for the project steering committee, and; a draft workplan for the first year of implementation. In addition, a cross-departemental working group will be set up at UNIDO.
The intervention’s total budget is 1,781,445 EUR, out of which UNIDO will fund 200,000 EUR and Sida contributes with 17 MSEK. The project is expected to contribute to employment and to Sustainable Development Goals number 4 (education), 9 (innovation) and 17 (partnerships).

4.3 - By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
4.3 - Senast 2030 säkerställa alla kvinnor och män lika tillgång till yrkesutbildning och eftergymnasial utbildning, inklusive högskoleutbildning, av god kvalitet till en överkomlig kostnad.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sweden and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization for the project Learning and Knowledge development facility 2.0
Beslut om insats för UNIDO LKDF facilitering och innovativ kompetensutveckling

description.narrative: There has been no formal reporting yet however UNIDO commisioned a survey as well as a paper during the initial phase of LKDF 2.0. The survey was a joint collaboration between UNIDO's LKDF and the European Training Foundation (ETF). It was a global survey, carried out between May and July, to collect information from industries to explore the economic impact of COVID-19 and measures put in place by enterprises. The survey specifically addressed whether and how COVID-19 is impacting skills needs of enterprises and measures adopted to up-skill and re-skill workers to better face emergency needs and future prospects. It focused on three dimensions: i) the economic impact of COVID-19 on industrial enterprises, ii) the impact on skills and measures adopted by enterprises, and iii) safety at work and measures adopted by enterprises. A total of 334 companies responded to the survey, the majority from the manufacturing, utilities, trade and transportation sectors. Most companies (32% of respondents) were large enterprises with more than 249 employees, followed by small companies (28%) with 10 to 49 employees and medium size (23%) companies. The conclusions drawn from the survey are that enterprises recognize skills as a major issue when it comes to ensuring business development and continuity, in particular to face pressures generated by expected changes to production processes and business delivery, and ensure adequate skills of the personnel, in particular when expecting to lay off staff in the percentage of 21-30%. Also, the pandemic has changed and increased companies’ needs for skills and accelerated demand, but it has not changed what kind of skills they need, whether access to information and strategies for skills development, re-skilling and up-skilling. Furthermore, some major issues important to explore further in the future and discuss with both enterprises and public authorities were identified; diversity of public measures, clear communication strategies, the need to learn from innovators, and uplifting the role of skills and skills development. Overall, the conclusions of the survey points to the importance of ensuring more advocacy and awareness raising on the role of skills for enterprise development, and bring more evidence on how investment in skills, re-skilling and up-skilling is key for enterprise competitiveness and development. The concept paper, "Green Industrial Skills for a Sustainable Future", was commissoned by LKDF of UNIDO to explain the relevance of skills to enable the green transformation in the industrial sector, to examine what upcoming trends in greening the industry in developing countries imply for the necessary skills, what kind of skills/competencies are expected to play a role in greening the industry, and what interventions may be necessary to develop such skills. Lastly, drawing on experiences with such interventions in developing countries, it highlights what the pre-requisites are for effective skill development programs. Insights provided by the report seek to guide policy intervention to meet the demand for green skills needed to both effectively operate and to develop green technologies. The findings of the survey and the concept paper were discussed at the LKDF Forum 6-8 October 2020 which focused on the transition to a green economy and the need for green skills. Conclusions from the Forum will be further processed by LKDF and inform the design of its future activities to make it as effective and efficient as possible in achieving its overall objective: to contribute to establishing inclusive, sustainable, and innovative market oriented vocational training systems and job creation in Africa and elsewhere in the era of digitilisation and automation by facilitating knowledge sharing and supporting a wider innovative approach for Public Private Development Partnerships, PPDPs, in skills development.
