title.narrative: COVID-19 Programstöd till UN Womens landprogram
COVID-19 UN Women Strategic Note for DRC

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Ambassaden har sedan juli 2019 stöttat UN Womens landkontor med en övergångsfinansiering för slutfasen av deras strategiska plan för 2014-2018 som förlängdes för 2019. Intentionen var att efter det stödet ge långsiktigt stöd för den nya strategiska planen 2020-2024 och nu har UN Women därför ansökt om finansiering från ambassaden för den kommande femårsperioden.
UN Womens globala mål som organisation är att åstadkomma jämställdhet och stärka kvinnors egenmakt. Den strategiska planen för 2020-2024 speglar detta mål och innehåller UN Womens plan för hur de ska stödja den kongolesiska regeringen och det civila samhället och andra berörda aktörer att genomföra, övervaka och rapportera om DRK:s åtaganden om jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt. Strategiplanens fokusområden är samhällsstyrning och kvinnors politiska deltagande; kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt; utrota våld mot kvinnor; samt fred, säkerhet och humanitärt stöd.
Den totala budgeten för hela strategiperioden är 41 583 956 dollar. Sverige åtar sig genom detta beslut att stödja implementeringen av den strategiska planen med 5 miljoner SEK per år för de tre första åren. Kontrakt skrivs dock för hela perioden och intentionen är att ge ekonomiskt stöd även för de sista två åren men att omfattningen ska beslutas efter utvärdering av UN Womens arbete under de första åren. UN Women har i nuläget inte finansiering för hela budgeten. Andra stora givare är Kanada, Japan, Italien, Nederländerna och Tyskland som alla ger stöd till specifika projekt. Sverige är i nuläget den enda givaren som stöder landprogrammet med icke-öronmärkt stöd.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy has since July 2019 supported UN Women's DRC office with a bridging for the final, extended, year of their Strategic Note for 2014-2018, extended to cover 2019. The intention was to continue with a long-term support for the new Strategic Note 2020-2024. UN Women has therefore applied to the Embassy for financial support for the coming five-year period.
The global goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women. The Strategic Note for 2020-2024 is developed in that spirit and contains UN Women's plan for supporting the Congolese government and the civil society and other actors to implement, monitor, and report on the Congolese commitment regarding gender equality and women's empowerment. The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: Governance and Women's political participation; Women's economic empowerment; Ending violence against women; and Peace, security and humanitarian action.
The total budget for the five years of the Strategic Note is 41 583 956 USD. Sweden commits with this decision to support the implementation of the Strategic Note with 5 million SEK per year during the first three years. The agreement will however cover the complete strategy period and the intention is to provide financial support also for the last two years. The size of this contribution will be decided upon after assessment of UN Women's work during the first couple of years. UN Women has not at the moment secured funds for the total budget. Other large donors are Canada, Japan, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany, who are all funding specific projects. Sweden is the only donor providing non-earmarked core support.

The general goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women globally. All interventions, including in DRC, are based on this goal and UN Women DRC has formulated its vision accordingly: "An inclusive, peaceful, and prosperous Democratic Republic of Congo, where women, girls, boys and men are free and secured, enjoy equal rights, and have equal opportunities to access a better life, to make their own decisions to improve their living conditions in order to achieve sustainable peace, security, the respect of human rights and women's rights for the attainment of sustainable development goals" The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: 1) Governance and Women's political participation; 2) Women's economic empowerment; 3) Ending violence against women; 4) Peace, security and humanitarian action. Building on these priority areas, the Strategic Note has the following strategic impact areas and specific outcomes and outputs of the development results framework. Each strategic area outcome has a theory of change and is aligned with the outputs in the UN Women Global Strategic Plan as well as the UNSDCF outcomes. 1. Governance and Women Political Participation Outcome 1.1: By 2024, public institutions, the media and civil society, at both central and decentralized levels, effectively exercise their roles for a peaceful, effective and inclusive democratic governance that is conducive to citizen participation and the strengthening of the rule of law. Outcome 1.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC, more specifically the most vulnerable (women, children, refugees and displaced people) will enjoy their human rights, in particular equitable access to justice (including juvenile justice), legal identity and protection, through strengthening judicial and security systems, the monitoring capacities of civil society organizations on human rights and institutional accountability. 2. Women’s economic empowerment Outcome 2.1: By 2024, Congolese people are enjoying sustainable inclusive economic growth driven by agricultural transformation, economic diversification open to innovation and the promotion of young women's entrepreneurship Outcome 2.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC benefit from inclusive social protection and a demographic dividend driven by demographic control and the empowerment of young people and women 3. Ending violence against women Outcome 3. Populations, especially the most vulnerable, enjoy equitable, quality and sustainable access to basic social services, including HIV/AIDS. 4. Peace, security and humanitarian action Outcome 4.1: By 2024, the prevalence of violence and armed conflict is reduced and the security of people and property is improved, especially for vulnerable people, including refugees/displaced persons, women and young people. Outcome 4.2: By 2024, humanitarian organizations and government humanitarian organizations are providing a coordinated, rapid and effective humanitarian response to those affected by crises in accordance with humanitarian standards and principles to reduce the excess mortality and over-morbidity of those affected. And in management and operations (OEEF - organisational effectiveness and efficiency Results Framework) there are four output clusters:. 1) Enhanced coordination, coherence and accountability of the UN system for gender equality commitment; 2) Increased engagement of partners in support of UN Women’s mandate; 3) Enhanced quality of programs through knowledge, innovation, RBM and evaluation; 4) Improved management of financial and human resources in pursuit of results. The separate project proposal for the response to the corona virus, sets the goal as: Effective management, prevention and response to the Covid-19 benefitting women, girls, boys and men, through adoption of strategic gender responsive approaches at community and local and national levels. Outcome 1. Incidence and impact of GBV is mitigated and minimised within local, national and COVID-response measures; Outcome 2. Social protection mechanisms and economic stimulus packages properly serve women and girls and are effectively targeted at their situations; Outcome 3: The broader public, and in particular men and boys, are supportive of and practise the equal sharing of unpaid care work arising from measures to manage the spread of COVID-19.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Ambassaden har sedan juli 2019 stöttat UN Womens landkontor med en övergångsfinansiering för slutfasen av deras strategiska plan för 2014-2018 som förlängdes för 2019. Intentionen var att efter det stödet ge långsiktigt stöd för den nya strategiska planen 2020-2024 och nu har UN Women därför ansökt om finansiering från ambassaden för den kommande femårsperioden.
UN Womens globala mål som organisation är att åstadkomma jämställdhet och stärka kvinnors egenmakt. Den strategiska planen för 2020-2024 speglar detta mål och innehåller UN Womens plan för hur de ska stödja den kongolesiska regeringen och det civila samhället och andra berörda aktörer att genomföra, övervaka och rapportera om DRK:s åtaganden om jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt. Strategiplanens fokusområden är samhällsstyrning och kvinnors politiska deltagande; kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt; utrota våld mot kvinnor; samt fred, säkerhet och humanitärt stöd.
Den totala budgeten för hela strategiperioden är 41 583 956 dollar. Sverige åtar sig genom detta beslut att stödja implementeringen av den strategiska planen med 5 miljoner SEK per år för de tre första åren. Kontrakt skrivs dock för hela perioden och intentionen är att ge ekonomiskt stöd även för de sista två åren men att omfattningen ska beslutas efter utvärdering av UN Womens arbete under de första åren. UN Women har i nuläget inte finansiering för hela budgeten. Andra stora givare är Kanada, Japan, Italien, Nederländerna och Tyskland som alla ger stöd till specifika projekt. Sverige är i nuläget den enda givaren som stöder landprogrammet med icke-öronmärkt stöd.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Embassy has since July 2019 supported UN Women's DRC office with a bridging for the final, extended, year of their Strategic Note for 2014-2018, extended to cover 2019. The intention was to continue with a long-term support for the new Strategic Note 2020-2024. UN Women has therefore applied to the Embassy for financial support for the coming five-year period.
The global goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women. The Strategic Note for 2020-2024 is developed in that spirit and contains UN Women's plan for supporting the Congolese government and the civil society and other actors to implement, monitor, and report on the Congolese commitment regarding gender equality and women's empowerment. The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: Governance and Women's political participation; Women's economic empowerment; Ending violence against women; and Peace, security and humanitarian action.
The total budget for the five years of the Strategic Note is 41 583 956 USD. Sweden commits with this decision to support the implementation of the Strategic Note with 5 million SEK per year during the first three years. The agreement will however cover the complete strategy period and the intention is to provide financial support also for the last two years. The size of this contribution will be decided upon after assessment of UN Women's work during the first couple of years. UN Women has not at the moment secured funds for the total budget. Other large donors are Canada, Japan, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany, who are all funding specific projects. Sweden is the only donor providing non-earmarked core support.

The general goal of UN Women as an organisation is to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of women globally. All interventions, including in DRC, are based on this goal and UN Women DRC has formulated its vision accordingly: "An inclusive, peaceful, and prosperous Democratic Republic of Congo, where women, girls, boys and men are free and secured, enjoy equal rights, and have equal opportunities to access a better life, to make their own decisions to improve their living conditions in order to achieve sustainable peace, security, the respect of human rights and women's rights for the attainment of sustainable development goals" The priority areas of the Strategic Note 2020-2024 are: 1) Governance and Women's political participation; 2) Women's economic empowerment; 3) Ending violence against women; 4) Peace, security and humanitarian action. Building on these priority areas, the Strategic Note has the following strategic impact areas and specific outcomes and outputs of the development results framework. Each strategic area outcome has a theory of change and is aligned with the outputs in the UN Women Global Strategic Plan as well as the UNSDCF outcomes. 1. Governance and Women Political Participation Outcome 1.1: By 2024, public institutions, the media and civil society, at both central and decentralized levels, effectively exercise their roles for a peaceful, effective and inclusive democratic governance that is conducive to citizen participation and the strengthening of the rule of law. Outcome 1.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC, more specifically the most vulnerable (women, children, refugees and displaced people) will enjoy their human rights, in particular equitable access to justice (including juvenile justice), legal identity and protection, through strengthening judicial and security systems, the monitoring capacities of civil society organizations on human rights and institutional accountability. 2. Women’s economic empowerment Outcome 2.1: By 2024, Congolese people are enjoying sustainable inclusive economic growth driven by agricultural transformation, economic diversification open to innovation and the promotion of young women's entrepreneurship Outcome 2.2: By 2024, people living in the DRC benefit from inclusive social protection and a demographic dividend driven by demographic control and the empowerment of young people and women 3. Ending violence against women Outcome 3. Populations, especially the most vulnerable, enjoy equitable, quality and sustainable access to basic social services, including HIV/AIDS. 4. Peace, security and humanitarian action Outcome 4.1: By 2024, the prevalence of violence and armed conflict is reduced and the security of people and property is improved, especially for vulnerable people, including refugees/displaced persons, women and young people. Outcome 4.2: By 2024, humanitarian organizations and government humanitarian organizations are providing a coordinated, rapid and effective humanitarian response to those affected by crises in accordance with humanitarian standards and principles to reduce the excess mortality and over-morbidity of those affected. And in management and operations (OEEF - organisational effectiveness and efficiency Results Framework) there are four output clusters:. 1) Enhanced coordination, coherence and accountability of the UN system for gender equality commitment; 2) Increased engagement of partners in support of UN Women’s mandate; 3) Enhanced quality of programs through knowledge, innovation, RBM and evaluation; 4) Improved management of financial and human resources in pursuit of results. The separate project proposal for the response to the corona virus, sets the goal as: Effective management, prevention and response to the Covid-19 benefitting women, girls, boys and men, through adoption of strategic gender responsive approaches at community and local and national levels. Outcome 1. Incidence and impact of GBV is mitigated and minimised within local, national and COVID-response measures; Outcome 2. Social protection mechanisms and economic stimulus packages properly serve women and girls and are effectively targeted at their situations; Outcome 3: The broader public, and in particular men and boys, are supportive of and practise the equal sharing of unpaid care work arising from measures to manage the spread of COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Helvetas-Fast Avfall-WASH COVID-19 räddningsinsatser i Bolivia
COVID-19 Helvetas-Solid Waste-WASH COVID-19 emergency response in Bolivia

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Governments should consider the management of basic services such as water, sanitation and solid waste as essential public services within the framework of the response to COVID-19, in order to directly minimize impacts on health and the environment (rapid and uncontrolled spread of the virus in cities).
Management measures should consider all types of waste, including medical, domestic and hazardous waste, because there is a lot of pressure on the water supply service and large quantities of possibly infectious waste (chinstraps, masks, gloves, used or expired medicines and other contaminated items), which can easily be mixed with common waste, increasing the risk exposure of workers in the service providers. Therefore, it is necessary to consider the necessary biosafety measures to minimize such risk.
The disinfection procedures for contact and transit areas in places with a large influx of people, food supply areas, health service infrastructure, and military and police personnel facilities are other key activities that should be taken into account.
Finally, another problem that must be addressed is the issue of communication (access to information, training, and awareness) both for health service personnel, technical support teams that have been working on the response, and the population in general, through campaigns, technical assistance, and/or support in the dissemination of existing materials.
Within the framework of the health emergency, HELVETAS (as a humanitarian actor in the country) along with Agua Tuya and SwissContact (the three current partners with the Embassy in different contributions) have requested the financial assistance of the Embassy to support an emergency response in the WASH and solid waste sector.
The project is aimed at contributing to the prevention and containment of COVID-19 infection with emphasis on the management of environmental sanitation, cleaning and disinfection services in the municipalities of La Paz, El Alto and Montero. The expected amount of the whole contribution is 3 million SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Hanteringen av grundläggande behov som vatten, sanitet och fast avfall är en väsentlig offentlig service i bekämpningen av Covid-19. Sådan service kan minska virusets påverkan på hälsa och miljö (framförallt dess snabba och okontrollerade spridning i städer). Åtgärder för hanteringen av olika typer av avfall (mediciniskt, hushålls- och farligt avfall) är också betydelsefulla, då sådant avfall annars kan påverka vattenförsörjningen. Det finns också en risk för att smittsamt avfall blandas med vanligt avfall. Smittsamt avfall är exempelvis maskar, handskar, utgångna mediciner, och diverse produkter som kan bära smitta. Exponering för dessa typer av avfall utgör även en risk för den personal som upprätthåller avfallshantering och sanitetstjänster. Det är därför viktigt att genomföra nödvändiga åtgärder för biosäkerhet i avfallshanteringen i syfte att minska riskerna.
Åtgärder för desinfektion av kontakt- och transitplatser där folksamlingar kan bildas (exempelvis matbutiker, sjukhus, samt arbetsplatser för militär och polis) är ytterligare en viktig punkt som måste beaktas.
Slutligen måste svårigheter relaterade till behovet av fungerande kommunikation uppmärksammas (tillgång till information, utbildning och medvetenhet). Sådana åtgärder är av vikt för personal sysselsatt med hälsovård, smittspridning, samt befolkningen i stort. Behovet av kommunikation kan mötas med upplysningskampanjer, teknisk rådgivning, och/eller stöd till spridning av befintlig information.
I den aktuella situationen har Helvetas (som varande en humanitär aktör i Bolivia) i samarbete med AguaTuya och SwissContact ansökt om ekonomiskt stöd från Sida för att stödja krisåtgärder inom vatten-, sanitet- och avfallssektorerna. Alla tre aktörer är etablerade motparter för Sida.
Projektets syfte är att bidra till förebyggandet och begränsningen av Covid-19, med fokus på miljösanering, rengöring och desinfektion av offentliga miljöer i La Paz, El Alto och Montero. Det förväntade bidraget uppgår till tre miljoner svenska kronor.

The overall objective of the contribution is to minimize the risk of COVID-19 infection of personnel operating environmental sanitation services, and thus ensure their continuity in spite the health emergency.
This has been done through the support to the selected municipalities in: -The development of contingency plans and its implementation through the provision of personal safety garments and other inputs for the protection of workers of environmental sanitation services, - Providing training in cleaning and disinfection of people’s high concentration areas - Technical assistance for communication and public information processes.

tag.narrative: 11.5 - By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations.

11.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet dödsfall och antalet människor som drabbas av katastrofer, inklusive vattenrelaterade katastrofer. Även tillse att de direkta ekonomiska förlusterna till följd av sådana katastrofer, i form av lägre global BNP, minskar väsentligt. Särskilt fokus bör ligga på att skydda de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer.

description.narrative: The Project was executed through the HELVETAS Swiss Intercooperation (HELVETAS) as the lead institution with Swisscontact and Aguatuya Foundation as the main third parties. Five activities have been planned during the whole implementation: Activity 1 Technical Assistance to Municipalities and WASH utilities in the design and implementation of contingency plans. Helvetas has developed “a service continuity tool in the context of COVID-19”. Its aim was to achieve continuity of vital services that are provided in municipalities and WASH utilities during the health emergency by limiting the exposure and protecting the personnel performing essential functions. The instrument has been validated in the water and sanitation utility of La Paz and El Alto (EPSAS) which is the biggest provider in Bolivia. It has been implemented in the municipalities of El Alto and the water and sanitation utilities of Montero and La Guardia. Helvetas along with their partners have also developed protocols for the provision of urban cleaning services. These protocols seek to improve the capacity of the municipalities to guarantee the continuity of operations in contexts of health emergencies where their employees are highly exposed to contagion due to the nature of their activities. It has been mainly implemented in the Municipality of La Guardia. Activity 2 Strengthen capacities through training courses to the technical staff, which was at risk of contagion due to their work in environmental sanitation: This specific activity has been carried out by Swisscontact through the National Institute of Health Laboratories (INLASA). The training activities have been developed in 38 health care establishments (including three WASH utilities and municipalities) making a total of 6,135 officials from the health sector and 224 officials from COSMOL and the company that provides waste collection and transportation services in the municipality of La Paz, La Paz Limpia. In order to standardize critical processes in health establishments, specific guidelines have been prepared in order to minimize the risk of this personnel. Activity 3 Provision of protection items (biosecurity inputs) to the technical staff within municipalities and WASH utilities. The project team has contacted the beneficiaries (WASH utilities and Municipalities) to confirm the main necessities for personal protection, defining the key items that were needed. It is important to mention that during the process of purchase, due to the high demand for many of these inputs, the prices of various items (disposable coveralls, chinstraps, among others) were more expensive and there was little availability of the required quantity. However, Helvetas has manged to deal with this situation. During the months of May and June, personal protection items were delivered to the autonomous municipal governments of La Paz and El Alto (for the workers in charge of the final disposal of solid waste generated in the landfills Saka Churu and Villa Ingenio) and EPSAS (for the workers that were working in the front line). In May and July, personal protection items were delivered to COSMOL (the WASH utility of Motero) and COSPLAG LR (the WASH Utility of La Guardia), contributing to the sustainability and continuity of the environmental sanitation services. In the month of July, EPSAS and the municipality of La Paz, given the increase of positive cases among their workers, requested additional support with personal protection elements to guarantee the continuity of work and prevent contagion. To meet this need, funds have been used from the contingency budget line. Activity 4- Provision of equipment and supplies for cleaning and disinfecting places with a high influx of people. In the months of May and June, supplies for cleaning and disinfection of public spaces with a high influx of people in the municipalities of La Paz and El Alto have been delivered. The main areas have been markets and public roads, reaching approximately 180 public spaces. In July, the Autonomous Municipal Government of El Alto, has requested additional support for the provision of “granular chlorine” to continue the cleaning and disinfection activities in public spaces due to the increase in cases in this city. To cover this need, funds have been used from the budget line for contingencies. In July, supplies for cleaning and disinfection of public spaces with a high influx of people were delivered in the municipalities of La Guardia achieving the disinfection of approximately 30 spaces. The logistics of this specific activity have been coordinated with the Vice Ministry of Civil Defense. Activity 5: Support the generation and dissemination of communication and information campaigns. A communication strategy has been implemented in the municipalities of El Alto, La Paz, La Guardia, Montero, producing differentiated messages to reach vulnerable groups, groups exposed to possible contagion (personnel who clean and disinfect public spaces, hospital waste operators and WASH Utilities) and the general population. The intended message has been oriented to promote a sense of co-responsibility in prevention, solid waste management and in the implementation of cleaning and disinfection measures. All communication actions have included an intercultural, gender and social equity approach. The contents have been disseminated through mass media and social networks (all the details of the messages and its dissemination are specified in the narrative report). Activity 6: Mega Tracking in La Paz This activity has not been planned in the original project document. However, and due to the high rate cases in the city of La Paz, the municipality has requested extra support to carry out this specific task. The Departmental Health Service of La Paz (SEDES) requested HELVETAS’ support for the transport of personnel to strengthen the operational action of the mega tracing in the city of La Paz. Having a small balance still to be executed and seeing the criticality of the epidemiological curve of contagion by COVID-19 in the department of La Paz, during the month of August, it was considered opportune to support SEDES in this operation of vital importance to contain the spread of the virus, especially in the municipalities of El Alto and La Paz. In this sense, and with a proper coordination within the Embassy, the request was carried out with the provision of transport and communication material on contagion prevention measures. This activity has been extremely important and has led the municipality and the National Government to take adequate measures regarding the de-confinement of cities and subsequent preventive measures based on an adequate strategy. Financial Report The budget execution of the Solid Waste-WASH COVID-19 emergency response in Bolivia Project for the period between April 27 and August 31, 2020 has been done according to the annex C specified in the agreement. As it has been mentioned above, some additional activities have been carried out under the contingency item budget line, in coordination with the Embassy. The accounting base of the project has been made under the modified cash base (mixed)” since most of the transactions were recorded under the cash method, except for the last payments pending at the end of the project which were carried out after the activity period ended (audit, etc.). The transactions incurred during the period of activities has been done applying the exchange rate of the single payment: 0.68069691 Bs / SEK (according to the bank). There has been a loss due to exchange differences of around Bs81,502.38 (SEK 107,602.93). This amount has been adjusted in the Contingency item budget line without affecting the expected results. Audit Report No major observations have been found in the audit report. Helvetas has complied with all the requirements.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19
COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Tbilisi for funding of one million and twenty thousand SEK to contribute to the "Georgia Red Cross Society’s Emergency Response to COVID-19" in Georgia during the period of three months, May-July 2020.
The intervention aims at contribute to preventing the spread of the Coronavirus and staying healthy by following: 1) Basic human needs of those affected by the new coronavirus outbreak have been met through provision of Red Cross services (food distribution, psychological first aid, psychosocial support, stress management, healthy lifestyle, incl. personal hygiene, etc.), as well as personal protective equipment to volunteer workers and Red Cross staff; 2) Raised awareness of the general public, local communities, mass media, and civil society sector through information campaigns as well as online training carried out by well mobilized and trained Red Cross and community volunteers.
The GRCS's open emergency plan with total budget is around 7.5 million SEK, for which the GRCS has made an open call and till now managed to mobilize already more than 6 million SEK. Among other donors, the Embassy of Swiss Confederation in Georgia and USAID Georgia have already contributed to the GRCS response plan.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Georgiska Röda Korset (GRCS) har ansökt om stöd från svenska ambassaden i Tbilisi om en budget på 1 020 000 MSEK för att bidra till organisationens kris- och beredskapsrespons för COVID-19 , under perioden maj - juli 2020.
Insatsen syfte är att bidra till att förebygga spridning av coronaviruset samt att upprätthålla en god folkhälsa genom följande målsättningar: 1) Möta grundläggande mänskliga behov bland den del av befolkningen drabbats hårt av det nya Coronaviruset, genom Röda Korsets tjänster (matdistribution, första hjälpen till psykologiskt drabbade, psykosocialt stöd, stresshantering, hälsosam livsstil inklusive personlig hygien, osv.), även skyddsutrustning till volontärer och Röda Korsets personal; 2) Öka medvetenheten inom samhället genom informationskampanjer och webbaserade utbildningar genomförda av mobiliserade och utbildade Röda Korset- och samhällsvolontärer.
GRCS:s kris- och beredskapsrespons för COVID-19 har en total budget på 7,5 MSEK, varav drygt 6 MSEK hittills har mobiliserats genom öppet. Bland andra bidragsgivarna återfinns bland andra USAID och den schweiziska ambassaden i Georgien.

National Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, Georgia

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

description.narrative: The following key results were achieved by he partner, Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS): - GRCS has provided the humanitarian aid and distributed in total 1,230 food and hygiene parcels to lonely, older people and persons with special needs in different regions of Georgia, as well as provided parcels to the National Tuberculosis Center. - Through, GRCS Emergency Appeal, up to 5,000 volunteers and 4,500 public servants and NGO employees were trained on COVID-19 and safety measures. - The GRCS volunteers carried out activities, such as information campaigns, supporting health workers in COVID-19 testing, provision of psychological first aid through the GRCS hotline service to minimise risks that the people, especially, lonely, older people and persons with special needs were facing. Through the hotline service, the GRCS has also managed to help up to 8,000 citizens of Georgia. - Out of above-mentioned volunteers,over 100 volunteers were involved in the implementation of this project. These volunteers, who were trained and equipped with personal protective items,were delivering services to the affected people in shifts and disseminating the risk communication messages along with the WHO recommendations to local communities in target locations. - The GRCS has developed, published and disseminated COVID-related information educational materials like posters, leaflets,brochures, as well as prepared the videoson COVID-19 and the recommendations to prevent and control the spread of COVID-19, thus encouraging the people to stay at home and safe. These materials have been published in Georgian, Azerbaijani,Armenian, Ossetian, and Abkhazian languages, and disseminated among the entire population, national minorities among them. - The anti-COVID-19 operations and services have been well coordinated with the central government and the municipalities’ authorities, as well as with non-state actors. Challenge for the GRCS during the implementation, has been the transition to doing more and more activities online, including the coordination of these activities, which GRCS successfully managed. As part of the monitoring measures, the Embassy representatives have also made field visit to observe the distribution of the parcels at the National Center for the Tuberculosis first hand and also spoke to the Center's representative about the significance of such support.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2021
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Reformsamarbete med Östeuropa, Västra Balkan och Turkiet 2014-2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Purpose The purpose of the contribution is to support the implementation of the continental Covid-19 strategy "Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak". The strategy was adopted by the African Union (all Africa's 55 health ministers/health ministries) on February 22, 2020 during a crisis meeting. The strategy has two overarching goals: to prevent severe disease and death from Covid-19 infection in member states and to minimize the social and economic consequences of the Covid-19 outbreak.
An Addendum to the strategy has also been developed, the AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, which includes specific reference to ensure access to basic health care, including maternal and child health care during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Henceforth, it should be noted that the reference to strategy includes both the Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak” and its Addendum. The strategy includes the following pillars: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; and Science, Standards and Regulations.
Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a specialized agency of the African Union. Africa CDC has been tasked by the African Union to implement the strategy.
Sida intends to support the Africa CDC with 20 million SEK to implement the pillars focused on Coordination and Collaboration and Risk Communication and Social Engagement.
This has been determined in consultation with the EU and other member states that constitute Team Europe, which includes Sweden. The arrangement means that the EU and the member states (Spain, Sweden, Germany and Austria) are coordinated through a joint budget and work plan and joint reporting (both narrative and financial, including audit). Team Europe's total support amounts to EUR 25.85 million (includes SEK 20 million from Sida). Attached document “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” sets out all relevant details. However, it should be noted that Sweden will enter into a bilateral/separate agreement with Africa CDC.
Sida will contribute to Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak and its Addendum through two other contributions: WHO-AFRO (SEK 30 million) and Together4SRHR (SEK 30 million through an amendment to the agreement). Sida views the contributions as three parts of a coherent support in line with the above strategy, and comprises a total of SEK 80 million.
The strategy is implemented through the Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), where Africa CDC, UN and AU member countries lead working groups, and through Africa CDC's Incident Management System (IMS). A number of partners, both UN and non-state actors, also contribute to the implementation of the strategy.
These implementing partners are financed either directly by aid donors who finance supplementary efforts, or via Africa CDC, which then transfers funds to implementing partners.
Context The reason that the contribution (without an explicit focus on SRHR) is funded by the regional SRHR strategy is because of the expected consequences of COVID-19. These are anticipated to be dramatic and all-encompassing regarding the development spectrum – encompassing e.g., social and economic aspects.
Africa CDC reports that with regards to its member states that there on 25 June 2020 was: 337,315 cases; and 8,863 deaths. Clearly, it is important to note that these are only reported/confirmed cases and that numbers rapidly increase daily.
Despite the various measures in place, the virus is likely to spread further and likely to continue to have significant impacts on e.g., the economy and livelihoods of the populations of the African continent. The social, health and development impacts of the pandemic on the continent are currently devastating and could signify a reversal of the development gains of the previous decades - there are already evidence that point to this direction.
The World Bank estimates that Sub-Saharan African economies could lose between USD 37 to USD 79 billion in 2020 due to consequences of COVID-19. Economic growth could contract from 2.4% in 2019 to -5.1% in 2020, bringing about the first recession in 25 years.
Sida notes that a challenge attached to the contribution could be longer term institutional strengthening and sustainability given that the focus and purpose is intertwined with COVID-19 and its trajectory. The agreement will cover a one year implementation period and entail a one-off disbursement. Nonetheless, there are reasons to assume that there will rippling effects and that the contribution will help also to strengthen Africa’s national public health institutions’ capacities to reduce the overall disease burden on the continent – beyond the COVID-19 pandemic. The issue of sustainability will be an ongoing dialogue issue between Sweden, Africa CDC, the EU and other relevant stakeholders.
Sida recognizes that the work of Africa CDC is crucial as health is a development issue that affects the economic, social and security concerns of countries and regions. This is especially apparent when infections or epidemics occur as became apparent during the Ebola outbreak in West Africa in 2014/2015 and again during the current COVID-19 pandemic.
Sida also takes note of the precarious situation on the African continent, which currently faces the burden of communicable and non-communicable diseases (NCDs), and injury and trauma. This is combined with fragile health systems and inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene infrastructure, population mobility that will make key preventing measures such as physical distancing very difficult to uphold, and contribute to increase susceptibility for unrest.
Challenges resulting from several infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, TB and malaria), maternal mortality as well as outbreaks such as yellow fever, cholera and natural disasters (as a result of climate change and conflict), still affect the continent adversely and continue to pose serious threats alongside the current COVID-19 pandemic, which will likely cause widespread illness and death in Africa (according to Africa CDC). One factor that could mitigate deaths in Africa is demography; more than 50 percent of the population is under 20 years old, a group that has been relatively spared from illness and death from COVID-19 across the world.
Overall with regards to health security, the Ebola crisis in 2014-2015 highlighted the unpreparedness of health systems in Africa. It was then made clear that health systems in Africa are unable to adequately cope with major health crises. Urgent and collective action is now needed to protect the African region from the health security threat that the COVID-19 pandemic poses.
It is clear that capacity gaps are due to insufficient resources (financial, human, and logistics) and fragmented services. Furthermore, limited community engagement, weak health systems, inadequate inter-country collaborations, and limited effective partnerships.
Across the world, African countries are least prepared for epidemics or pandemics. All African countries lack foundational health systems capacities for vital epidemic and pandemic response and national health security is fundamentally weak across the African continent. There are also severe weaknesses in countries’ abilities to prevent, detect, and respond to health emergencies; vulnerabilities to political, socioeconomic, and environmental risks that can confound outbreak preparedness and response; and, a lack of adherence to international norms.
Africa CDC acts now to support African countries to address these gaps through coordination and to strengthen preparedness and response through partnerships.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Syfte Insatsens syfte är att stödja implementeringen av den kontinentala covid-19 strategin ”Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”. Strategin antogs av den Afrikanska Unionen (alla Afrikas 55 hälsoministrar/hälsoministerier) 22 februari 2020 under ett krismöte. Strategin har två övergripande mål: att förebygga svår sjukdom och död av Covid-19 infektion i medlemsländer och att minimera sociala och ekonomiska konsekvenser av covid-19 utbrottet.
Ett tillägg finns även till strategin, AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, som inkluderar specifik referens till att säkerställa tillgång till grundläggande hälsosjukvård, inklusive mödrabarnhälsovård under covid-19 pandemin.
Med strategin menas hädanefter både Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum.
Strategin omfattar följande pelare: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; och Science, Standards and Regulations.
Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) är en institution som tillhör den Afrikanska Unionen. Africa CDC har av den Afrikanska Unionen fått uppdraget att implementera strategin.
Sida avser att stödja Africa CDC med 20 miljoner SEK för implementerandet av pelare fokuserade på Coordination and Collaboration och Risk Communication and Social Engagement.
Detta har bestämts i samråd med EU och andra medlemsstater som utgör Team Europe där Sverige ingår. Upplägget innebär at EU och medlemsstaterna (Spanien, Sverige, Tyskland och Österrike) är samordnade under en gemensam budget och arbetsplan och gemensam rapportering (både narrativ och finansiell, inklusive revision). Team Europes totala stöd utgör EUR 25,85 miljoner (inkluderar 20 miljoner SEK från Sida). Bilagt dokument “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” redogör för alla relevanta detaljer. Det bör dock noteras att Sverige kommer att ingå ett bilateralt/separat avtal med Kommissionen för den Afrikanska Unionen.
Sida kommer att bidra till Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum genom två andra insatser WHO-AFRO (30 miljoner SEK) och Together4SRHR (30 miljoner SEK genom en avtalsändring). Sida ser på insatserna som tre delar av ett sammanhållet stöd i linje med ovan nämnda strategi, och omfattar totalt 80 miljoner SEK.
Den kontinentala COVID-19 strategin implementeras genom Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), där Africa CDC, FN och AU:s medlemsländer leder arbetsgrupper, och genom Africa CDC’s Incident Management System (IMS). Ett antal partners, både FN och ickestatliga aktörer, bidrar också till att implementera strategin.
Dessa implementerande partners finansieras antingen direkt av biståndsgivare som finansierar kompletterande insatser, eller via Africa CDC som sedan vidareförmedlar medel till implementerande partners.
Kontext Anledningen till att insatsen (utan ett uttryckligt fokus på SRHR) finansieras av den regionala SRHR-strategin är på grund av de förväntade konsekvenserna av COVID-19. Dessa förväntas vara dramatiska och allomfattande vad gäller utvecklingsspektrumet - som t.ex. omfattar sociala och ekonomiska aspekter, och COIVD-19 riskerar att tränga undan annan grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård, inklusive tjänster för sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa.
Africa CDC rapporterar att det bland sina medlemsländer, den 25 juni 2020 ,fanns: 337 315 bekräftade fall av Covid-19; och 8 863 bekräftade dödsfall till följd av Covid-19. Det bör noteras att dessa endast avser rapporterade/bekräftad fall och att antalet snabbt ökar dagligen.
Trots att olika åtgärder har vidtagits kommer viruset enligt olika beräkningar att spridas ytterligare och fortsätta att ha betydande effekter på t.ex. ekonomin och livsmedelsförsörjningen på den afrikanska kontinenten. De sociala, hälso- och utvecklingseffekterna av pandemin på kontinenten är för närvarande förödande och kan innebära att utvecklingsvinningar under de senaste decennierna urholkas. Det finns redan bevis som pekar på denna riktning.
Världsbanken uppskattar att de afrikanska ekonomierna söder om Sahara kan förlora mellan 37 och 79 miljarder USD under år 2020 till följd av Covid-19 konsekvenser. Den ekonomiska tillväxten kan minska från 2,4% 2019 till -5,1% 2020, vilket skulle leda till den första lågkonjunkturen på 25 år.
Sida konstaterar att en utmaning kopplad till insatsen kan vara långsiktigt institutionellt stärkande och hållbarhet med tanke på att fokus och syfte är sammanflätade med Covid-19 och dess utveckling.
Avtalet täcker en implementeringsperiod på ett år och innebär en engångsutbetalning. Det finns emellertid skäl att anta att insatsen kommer att ha bredare effekter och att insatsen också kommer att bidra till att stärka Afrikas nationella folkhälsoinstitutioners kapacitet för att minska den totala sjukdomsbördan på kontinenten bortom Covid-19-pandemin. Hållbarhet kommer att vara en pågående dialogfråga mellan Sverige, Africa CDC, EU och andra relevanta aktörer.
Sida anser att Africa CDC:s arbete är mycket viktigt eftersom hälsa är en utvecklingsfråga som påverkar de ekonomiska, sociala och säkerhetsmässiga aspekterna i länder och regioner. Detta är särskilt uppenbart när det gäller infektioner eller epidemier. Detta visade sig under Ebola-utbrottet i Västafrika 2014/2015 och återigen under den nuvarande COVID-19-pandemi.
Sida noterar också den osäkra situationen på den afrikanska kontinenten, som för närvarande står inför bördan av smittsamma och icke-smittsamma sjukdomar, skador och trauma. Detta kombineras med bräckliga hälsosystem och otillräcklig infrastruktur för vatten, sanitet och hygien och stor befolkningsrörlighet. Detta kommer att göra viktiga förebyggande åtgärder som fysisk distansering mycket svåra att upprätthålla och öka risken för oroligheter.
Utmaningar till följd av flera infektionssjukdomar (t.ex. HIV, TB och malaria), mödradödlighet samt utbrott som gulafeber, kolera och naturkatastrofer (som ett resultat av klimatförändringar och konflikter), påverkar fortfarande kontinenten negativt och fortsätter att utgöra allvarliga hot tillsammans med den nuvarande Covid-19 pandemin, som sannolikt kommer att orsaka utbredd sjukdom och död i Afrika (enligt Africa CDC). En faktor som kan mildra dödsfall i Afrika är demografi; mer än 50 procent av befolkningen är under 20 år gammal, en grupp som över hela världen har relativt förskonats från sjukdom och död till följd av Covid-19.
Övergripande när det gäller hälsosäkerhet visade Ebolakrisen 2014–2015 att hälsosystem i Afrika inte kan hantera stora hälsokriser på ett tillfredsställande sätt. Brådskande och kollektiva åtgärder behövs nu för att skydda den afrikanska regionen från det hälsohot som Covid-19-pandemin utgör.
Det är uppenbart att kapacitetsbrister beror på otillräckliga resurser (ekonomiska, mänskliga och logistiska) och fragmenterade tjänster. Dessutom finns andra stora utmaningar, t.ex. begränsat samhällsengagemang, svaga hälsosystem, otillräckliga samarbeten mellan länder och begränsade effektiva partnerskap.
Över hela världen är afrikanska länder minst förberedda på att hantera epidemier eller pandemier. I alla afrikanska länder saknas grundläggande kapacitet bland hälsosystem för att effektivt bekämpa epidemier och pandemier. Det finns även allvarliga brister i ländernas förmåga att förebygga, upptäcka och bemöta hälsohot; hög utsatthet för politiska, socioekonomiska och miljömässiga risker som kan försvåra beredskap och hanterandet av utbrott; och bristande efterlevnad av internationella normer.
Africa CDC agerar nu för att stödja afrikanska länder att hantera dessa brister genom att samordna, och stärka beredskap och respons genom partnerskap.

The first and foremost purpose of the intended contribution is to enable Africa CDC to promptly and systematically implement “The Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”, endorsed by the AU. The articulated goals of the strategy are to: prevent severe morbidity and mortality from COVID-19 infection in African Union (AU) member states; and, to minimize social disruption and economic consequences of COVID-19 outbreaks. The strategy has two objectives: coordinate efforts of AU member states, AU agencies, WHO, and other partners and stakeholder to ensure synergy and minimize duplication; and, promote evidence-based public health practice for surveillance, prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and control of COVID-19. Consequently, beyond the pressing need to ensure 1) effective coordination and collaboration, the strategy (and the addendum - i.e., implementation plan) stipulates that efforts will be dedicated to: 2) Surveillance: Collect, analyze, and disseminate accurate, timely data about the epidemiology of COVID-19. 3) Laboratory: Ensure quality-assured testing for COVID-19 diagnosis, genotyping, and special studies. 4) Countermeasures: Support implementation of evidence-based interventions at individual and population-level to reduce COVID-19 transmission. 5) Healthcare preparedness: Strengthen capacity of healthcare facilities to manage surge in patient visits and to effectively identify, isolate, and manage people with COVID-19 infection. 6) Risk communication and social engagement: Provide guidance that is clear, comprehensible, evidence based, culturally appropriate, and adapted to special populations and circumstances. 7) Supply chain management: Establish and maintain supply chains for shared resources, including personal protective equipment, laboratory supplies and equipment, and, if available and necessary, medical countermeasures. 8) Special populations, settings, and policies: Assess and manage issues related to special populations (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons), analyze and guide on ethical and legal issues (e.g., quarantine, healthcare triage, travel, trade), and develop plans for continuity of essential public health operations (e.g., maternal child health programs, immunizations). 9) Science, standards and regulations: Ensure that timelyand coordinated scientific and policy information is made available to decision makers within AU member states. The Sida funds will be dedicated to pillar 1) effective coordination and collaboration and pillar 6) risk communication and social engagement. In terms of specific results, the Swedish contribution will primarily contribute to: -A more effectively functioning Africa CDC, including improved functions in regional coordination, epi analysis, and partnership development. -Reductions in disease spread in countries where community health workers were deployed due to more effective public health behaviors (e.g., physical distancing, mask wearing, hand washing etc.). This has been agreed with the EU and other member states, who will fund other pillars and results - all in a harmonized approach. Through the Team Europe, also the following results will be achieved (to be funded by other members): - Improvements in healthcare outcomes (e.g., lower spread of cases and less severe cases) in IDP and refugee camp settings. - Improved member state capacity in surveillance and detection through technical experts, trainings, and community health workers. - Increase in testing rates in countries where lab supplies are distributed. - Improvements in testing, tracing and treatment outcomes in countries where community health workers and rapid responders are deployed. The joint Team Europe work plan and budget outlines what the EU as an entity and each EU member state will fund, and should thus be consulted for details. It should be noted that the Swedish contribution has also been harmonized with the support to WHO-AFRO and the Together4SRHR platform and is in line with the relevant Swedish strategy for the regional SRHR team (see the appraisal plan regarding details pertaining to the 2 relevant Swedish government strategies).

description.narrative: The goal of the proposed programme is to mitigate the consequences of Covid-19 on the health system with provision of essential health commodities to ensure the continuation of essential health services delivery in 4 provinces of Zambia. The programme is intended to promote resilience of the health system as a mitigation for Covid-19 impact by ensuring essential health commodity security especially focused on vaccines, essential medicines and supplies for reproductive, maternal, newborn, child and adolescent health services. The aim is to serve an estimated 1 million people with primary health care services, 375 000 infants with routine vaccination services and 380 000 pregnant women with maternal health supplies. The programme will also procure and distribute personal protective equipment, oxygen concentrators and infection prevention supplies for 5 000 health workers to avoid Covid-19 infection and ensure a healthy and safe work environment. The supplies are estimated to serve patients for a period of 6 months but the programme duration will be 1,5 years to ensure consistent monitoring, oversight and follow-up as well as capacity-building. More specifically, the key results will be: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 3 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 2 months. UPDATE The key results have been updated to reflect the additional 15 Million SEK from Sida. These are some of the key results with sligthly revised figures: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). No change. - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 6 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 4 months. - An estimated 4000 newborns receiving quality essential newborn care services at 5 hospitals in the 4 provinces and at UTH Lusaka. NEW - 22 health facilities equipped with cold chain equipment. NEW - Provincial Vaccines Store in Muchinga restored. NEW - 4 hospitals equipped with recommissioned oxygen plants to treat critical patients including covid-19. NEW - 5 hospitals equipped with neonatal supplies for quality essential newborn care services and 30 health workers trained. NEW

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNICEF has applied to Sida for support to Multisectoral response to Covid 19: Building Resilient and Integrated Essential Services for Underserved Communities in Cox’s Bazar and Gazipur Districts, Bangladesh.
In partnership with the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) International and National Non-Governmental Organizations and Civil Society Organizations UNICEF proposes to contribute to the reduction of the adverse impacts of COVID-19 on poor and vulnerable children and women in two districts of Bangladesh. This project complements GoB’s commitment to achieve food security and improved nutrition, ensuring healthy lives and promoting wellbeing at all ages and elimination of different forms of violence to women and adolescent girls, by improving their human capabilities.
The Integrated Package of Services proposed are aligned with the Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan (BPRP) for COVID-19 health response and address the critical lifesaving interventions in nutrition, WASH, and protection including GBV and are essential to minimize the impact of the pandemic among vulnerable children and women. The proposal is developed in consultation with Government of Bangladesh and multisectoral partners.
The proposed one-year project will contribute to the following outcomes by addressing at the national level key issues of targeting and quality of social protection and in the districts of Gazipur and Cox's Bazar focused on strengthening systems and access to social protection and social services for women and children in poor and vulnerable communities by:
I. Enhanced capacity of essential services and personnel to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks and provide quality health, nutrition, child protection, GBV, water, hygiene, waste management and sanitation services
II. Advocate to expand the coverage and strengthen effectiveness of national social protection system and ensure the urgent release, reunification, and reintegration of children in juvenile detention facilities and other institutions.
III. Integrated support to the Bangladeshi host communities and Rohingya refugees undergoing treatment for COVID-19 at the 200 bed SARI ITC in Teknaf, Cox's Bazar District.
The intervention budget is 30 000 000 SEK and will be financed by Sida.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNICEF har ansökt till Sida om stöd till Sektorövergripande COVID-19 respons: Uppbyggnad av resilient och integrerad grundläggande service för utsatta grupper i Cox's Bazar och Gazipur i Bangladesh.
I samarbete med Bangladesh regering samt internationella och nationella civilsamhällsorganisationer vill UNICEF bidra till att minska de negativa effekterna av COVID-19 för fattiga och utsatta barn och kvinnor i två distrikt i Bangladesh. Detta projekt kompletterar Bangladesh regerings åtagande att nå livsmedelssäkerhet och förbättrad nutrition, säkerställa och främja god hälsa i alla åldrar och eliminera olika former av våld mot kvinnor och tonårsflickor genom att stärka kapacitet.
Den föreslagna insatsen är anpassad till Bangladeshs beredskaps- och responsplan (BPRP) för hälsorespons på COVID-19 och omfattar insatser inom nutrition, vatten och sanitet och skydd inklusive könsbaserat våld för att minimera effekterna av pandemin bland utsatta barn och kvinnor. Insatsen har utvecklats i samråd med Bangladeshs regering och partners inom flera sektorer.
Det föreslagna ettåriga projektet kommer att bidra till följande resultat genom att på nationell nivå ta itu med frågor kring inriktning och kvalitet på socialt skydd samt i distrikten Gazipur och Cox's Bazar med fokus på att stärka system och tillgång till socialt skydd och social service för kvinnor och barn i fattiga och utsatta områden genom:
I. Förbättrad kapacitet på service och personal för att respondera på COVID-19-utbrottet och tillhandahålla service inom hälsa, nutrition, barnskydd, könsbaserat våld, vatten, hygien, avfallshantering och sanitet.
II. Arbeta för att utvidga täckningen och stärka effektiviteten i det nationella sociala skyddssystemet och säkerställa ett snabbt frisläppande, återförening och återintegrering av barn vid ungdomsfängelser och andra institutioner.
III. Integrerat stöd till värdsamhällen och Rohingya-flyktingar som genomgår behandling för COVID-19 vid 200-bädds SARI ITC i Teknaf, Cox's Bazar-distrikt.
Insatsbudgeten är 30 000 000 SEK och kommer att finansieras av Sida.

The proposed one-year project will contribute to the following outcomes by addressing at the national level key issues of targeting and quality of social protection and in the two districts through an integrated package focused on strengthening systems and access to social protection and social services for women and children in poor and vulnerable communities by end of July 2021 through the following actions: I. Enhanced capacity of essential services and personnel to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks and provide quality health, nutrition, child protection, GBV, water, hygiene, waste management and sanitation services to underserved women, children and vulnerable communities in Gazipur District and City Corporation.II. Advocate to expand the coverage and strengthen effectiveness of national social protection system and ensure the urgent release, reunification, and reintegration of children in juvenile detention facilities and other institutions. III. Integrated support to the Bangladeshi host communities and Rohingya refugees undergoing treatment for COVID-19 at the 200 bed SARI ITC in Teknaf, CxB District. The proposed interventions will be implemented under the leadership of GoB within the existing structures including those at institutional and community levels. Systems strengthening, preparedness, and addressing key underlying issues will support governments efforts to improve effectiveness of national social security system and to suppress COVID-19 in the two districts. In CxB for instance, it is projected that at least 1,000 beds will be needed for an isolation and treatment centre for the expected COVID-19 cases both for Rohingya refugees and the host communities. In Gazipur, systems issues will be addressed to ensure adequate access to integrated social services. Evidence will be developed for policy engagement and policy influencing on social protection, public health and basic service delivery both in urban and rural Bangladesh. The interventions will also reduce protection risks for children and women including physical violence, trafficking, early marriages and child labour which are prevalent in the two districts. Lastly, the proposed budget of USD 3,108,949.80 will support the stipulated interventions, strengthening systems and communities, addressing underlying fragilities towards a more resilient approach to lower transmission of COVID-19 and to better respond to future public health challenges in Bangladesh.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution-Multisectoral response to COVID -19 UNICEF
